QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations how, in light of his failure last week to condemn the disruption by the Australian Council of Trade Unions of essential services to Queensland and his failure to support the reintroduction of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) legislation and to use the Trade Practices Act to ensure the continuation of essential services to Queensland, he proposes to back up his view, expressed as recently as last Saturday in Tasmania when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: No-one can question the right of the community to expect continued provision of essential services and not be subject to hardship because of interruption to those services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, of course, true that I made that statement in Tasmania last Saturday in a speech to the Tasmanian Industrial Relations Society. Of course, it has never been anything other than the position of this Government that we are concerned to ensure that persons employed in essential services maintain services as much as is possible so that the people who are dependent on those services are able to receive them. However, I think it must also be said that we are also aware of the point that in a democracy it is right that people in all walks of life have the right in the end to take industrial action to protect their industrial rights. We certainly say that people who are involved in essential services should have that right but they should exercise that right only in very exceptional circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not the position of this Government that we would deny the right to take industrial action to persons employed in essential services, but with that right to strike, which we believe they should have in a democracy, goes an obligation and a duty. That obligation and duty is to exercise that right in a very discriminate way and to exercise it only when there is an absolutely essential need for it. My concern is that in some areas of the economy there has been an increasing acceptance by some employees in essential services of the taking of strike action when in previous years-and certainly decades-there would not have been such an acceptance. One has only to look at the hospital industry to see that there has been a growing use of industrial action in that area, which I believe is a matter of growing concern.

I think it is a fact that employees in essential services need to be very cautious about the use of that right. We would support their having that right, but using it only in exceptional circumstances. I do not believe, as was implied in the honourable member's question, that better industrial relations in those industries will be obtained by taking the kind of draconian steps that have been taken by the Queensland Government. That will only lead to the suppression of industrial rights and we will not have good industrial relations. We may have very few stoppages, but we would have very bad industrial relations. We would have an embittered work force and bad productivity. That is not what would help this economy.

We believe that the approach taken by this Government, which has been to adopt a co-operative form of industrial relations, has been demonstrably successful. It has brought about the lowest level of industrial disputation in l7 years-far below the levels that occurred under the Fraser Government. It is clearly the most appropriate form of developing industrial relations in this country. The actions of the Queensland Government, in the other direction, only act to undermine all of the gains which have been achieved by the approach we have adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism been drawn to recent Press reports of a statement made by the Queensland Minister for Tourism that the Federal Government's policies on air charter are restricting international tourism to north Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see those reports. I was rather surprised, if not stunned, by the cover they were given in the Press. The truth about the matter is that the Government has received very few applications for charter flights from anywhere in the world. In fact, in total we have received four applications. I can tell members of the House-particularly the Queenslanders and particularly the honourable member for Leichhardt, who has an abiding interest in things relating to tourism in the north of Queensland-that the Government has acted very properly in every case. The first application came from Sterling Airways. It made an application last year to bring charter flights from Denmark and other parts of Scandinavia to Queensland. I can assure the House that this application was treated with full respect and with expedition by the Government. I have sighted some correspondence from Sterling Airways thanking the Government for its very prompt review of this application. Another application has been put to the Minister by All Nippon Airways from Japan. This application has also been treated with expedition and seriousness. It is interesting to note that this application has not at this stage been given official imprimatur by the Japanese Government. Certainly, we have had no indication that the Japanese Government is supporting it. Of course, that is a very necessary component of a successful application. There have been two other applications by East West Airlines.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is important to note that if the Queensland Minister for Tourism-who is certainly the most garrulous and probably the least effective of all the tourism Ministers in Australia-were half honest in discussing tourism in Queensland he would admit that what has happened in Queensland in the last two years has been a revolution in the tourism industry, almost totally because of the actions of this Government in promoting tourism in so many ways. I do not want to go through the gamut of areas, but something which it would be pertinent for the State Tourist and Travel Corporation to do would be to set up an information bureau at Cairns Airport. The Queensland Government is very gung ho about allowing charter flights to Cairns and it makes lots of noises about what it might do. Anybody who bothers to visit Cairns international and domestic airport will find that there is a self-help information bureau; one picks up a brochure if one can. I would have thought that if the Queensland Minister were sincere about developing tourism in the north of Queensland-upon which the economy of that State hangs so seriously-he would do the sorts of things for which the State tourist commissions are set up. This Government has certainly fulfilled its charter to bring more people into Australia and to promote greater tourism within Australia. It behoves the Queensland Government, particularly that garrulous Minister, to do something about fulfilling his charter as a State Minister and to stop trying to score political points about this Government and this Minister. I think our Government's record stands up greatly to examination.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether he is aware of reports that the Australian Council of Trade Unions intends to extend its hit list to over 200 companies. I refer the Minister to the concern expressed in a telex sent to the Prime Minister by the Board of the Confederation of Western Australian Industry (Inc) on Friday which stated, inter alia, in relation to the hit list:

QUESTION.PARA: Your Government's credibility is on the line. We urge you to take the strongest possible action to bring about responsible behaviour by the union movement. Failure to do so will, in our view, spell the beginning of the end of the union movement in this country and the credibility of your own Government.
In view of these concerns, does the Government intend to continue its policy of surrender to the ACTU?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made it quite clear that it does not support the campaign of industrial action being undertaken by the ACTU in relation to this matter. The Government has, of course, proposed a means by which all of that industrial action could be avoided. I was very pleased to see that this morning the head of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Williams, endorsed the fact that there should be discussions. He said on the AM program this morning that basically there is something to talk about and that it would be tragic for Australia if it became necessary for legislation ultimately to determine an industrial dispute. He also said that, without a doubt, there should be discussions. I believe that that, on the part of the most senior spokesman for business in this country, indicates an awareness by the business community that if there is to be a resolution of this matter it has to come about through negotiations between the parties involved.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe strongly that Mr Williams is right in taking that approach and that that is what all parties should be seeking to bring about. The intransigence of the Queensland Premier makes that very difficult but I think that, once it becomes realised more widely by the Australian community that business believes that the only way to resolve this dispute is by negotiations, surely there will be greater pressure on the Queensland Premier to accept that that is the way to resolve this matter and that his continued refusal to do so demonstrates on his part a determination not to resolve this matter but to keep unnecessary industrial confrontation and disputation going. That must be the only conclusion one can reach if he refuses to undertake negotiations which even the business leaders are saying would be appropriate.

I was rather amused to see that the Leader of the Opposition has a new definition of the right to strike. Last week honourable members will have heard the Leader of the National Party of Australia say to a gathering of kindred souls in Victoria that it was not true that the Queensland Government had removed the right to strike because there was still a right to strike; it was just that one was dismissed and lost all entitlements if one did so. The Leader of the Opposition, who now takes his orders from the Leader of the National Party, says the same thing. In a Press release on the weekend he said that the legislation does not prevent employees in the electricity industry exercising their right to strike but it does provide the employer, because it is an essential industry, with the power summarily to dismiss any person who goes on strike. What a great definition of rights that is! It is like saying that all Russians have the right to go into Red Square and protest but they will finish up in the Lubyanka if they do. That is the definition of rights that the Leader of the Opposition has; it is not a definition of rights anyone in this country would accept, apart from members of the Opposition who are simply using this whole exercise as an attempt to develop maximum political mileage and pursue a course which is making the resolution of this matter much more difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Do the preliminary results of the Australian Medical Association's plebiscite indicate that the overwhelming majority of Australia's doctors support a full return to normal services in New South Wales public hospitals? Do these results show that the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Barker are completely out of touch with the mainstream of the medical profession, as well as members of the general public who demand that this essential service should be restored?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly 6,000 replies have been received from some 32,000 doctors in this country in relation to the AMA plebiscite. Nationally, 8l per cent of all doctors polled favoured a return to work. In New South Wales the vote was 73 per cent in favour of resumption of normal services. Even among those who have currently withdrawn all or part of their services there was a 55 per cent vote in favour of a return to work. This comes on top of decisions made by various specialists last week to return to their hospital jobs in New South Wales and reflects the overwhelming view of the medical profession in Australia that the Government has offered a fair and generous peace package to settle the dispute in New South Wales. This has been accepted by the AMA, by most health organisations and by the vast majority of doctors.

ANSWER.PARA: There remain the militant surgeons who are still prepared to sacrifice their patients in their dispute with the Government. It should be pointed out that these people, having already brought the whole medical profession into contempt by their continuing attitude that their patients should be treated as pawns in their political dispute, are now going further in besmirching the profession because they now allege that their professional colleagues are simply ballot riggers. It is about time that the friends of the surgeons on the Opposition benches began to give them the same advice as the Liberal leader in New South Wales has been prepared to give them, and that is to get back to their jobs and stop making their patients suffer.
I remind the Opposition Leader again of what he said last week on the Queensland situation:

No responsible citizen can support the industrial muscle and blackmail that is being used against Australian citizens. When the essential services of the community are being held to ransom by a group of people who disagree with a government policy, then a government has no option but to move and move firmly.
Until the Opposition Leader is heard making similar comments about Dr Shepherd and Dr Aroney and their ilk, he will continue to be regarded as a man of double standards--

TALK.START.PARA: —We want a fair and equitable hospital system.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker continuously ignores requests from the Chair to cease interjecting.

—As I was saying, until the Opposition Leader is prepared to say the same things about Drs Aroney and Shepherd and their ilk, he will be seen as a man of double standards, with one standard for wealthy surgeons and an entirely different set of standards for ordinary working trade unionists.

In view of the Minister's statement last Thursday and again today that the Government did not condone the Australian Council of Trade Unions blockade of Queensland, did the Minister for Aviation confer with him prior to the issue of the notice of air movements-or notam-of last Wednesday that flight notification, flight planning and processing of aircraft movement services for regular public transport and regular cargo flights entering and exiting the State of Queensland would not be available on Friday? Were any efforts made to provide those services? Will the personnel concerned be paid for that day?

—It is my understanding that there was no refusal of any flight plans for commercial flights by air traffic controllers. There were, of course, no scheduled flights to Queensland, but not because of the actions of air traffic controllers in not receiving flight plans. There were private charter flights, and internal flights operated normally, but my understanding is that there was no such action by air traffic controllers.
—I am quite happy to give the Minister the document--
—Order! The honourable member has not the call.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to recent claims that the Federal Government is moving at tortoise pace towards improving training opportunities for young people. Will the Minister inform the House what progress the Government has made in this important area in response to recommendations of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the statement in this morning's Melbourne Age that the Government was moving at tortoise pace towards the development of new training arrangements for young people. I think that is a grossly unfair statement by the editorial writer in the Melbourne Age. The fact is that the Government is very concerned to develop new training arrangements for young people. We have now received three reports this year which have recommended to us the development of training arrangements-the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report on youth policy and the Bureau of Labour Market Research report on youth employment patterns. All of those reports said that the development of traineeships for young people was the appropriate way for the Government to go in improving the employment prospects for young people. We have therefore been embarked on a course of rapidly developing traineeships, but it must be understood, of course, that that cannot be achieved overnight.

ANSWER.PARA: What the Government is talking about is the development of a new form of program for young people commencing employment in this country outside of apprenticeships and other present structured training arrangements, which is a major development and must be introduced with the agreement of all major parties and with a full understanding by everyone of what is involved. That is something which cannot be done very quickly. What we have done is to embark upon a two-phase development of this arrangement. Firstly, we have virtually concluded the process of consulting all the relevant parties. We have one further round of discussions to go through the Australian Education Council. There have been discussions with the organised employers and the trade unions through the National Labour Consultative Council, with State governments and with the training and education sectors, and with that other one to come in a few days time we will have completed the first round of consultations.

Following that, we will move to the second phase-developing specific detail of the number of traineeship areas for next year. A pilot program will be operating in l986 in a number of industries. Those industries may differ from State to State, but the program will mean that several thousand traineeships will apply, we hope, for l986. I have been very encouraged to this stage by the in-principle support which has come from all parties. Of course, there is a lot of detail to develop and a number of problems to overcome, but there is strong support from all sections consulted to this stage and I can assure the editorial writer of the Melbourne Age that the development of the traineeships is a matter of very high priority, that work is proceeding as rapidly as is possible and that we will have a good pilot program operating in l986 in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the answer just given to this House by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, will the Minister for Aviation advise why the notice of air movement to which the question of the honourable member for Murray referred was issued; and are the personnel concerned being paid for that day?
—I do not have the details with me, but to the best of my knowledge a notam was issued. I am checking on that and I will provide the honourable member with a detailed response later in the day.
—Who authorised it?
—I said that I do not have the details. I will be happy to provide them to the honourable member later in the day.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What part is Australia playing in investigating the hypothesis of a nuclear winter resulting from either a limited or large scale nuclear exchange in the Northern Hemisphere?

—Most of the research being carried out in Australia which has a bearing on the nuclear winter hypothesis has been carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Atmospheric Research. Recently the Division proposed two new study projects, one involving a study on interhemispheric exchange relating to the likely environmental effects of a nuclear war in the Northern Hemisphere on Australia's climate and the other concerning research into transport into the Southern Hemisphere of particles injected by Northern Hemisphere nuclear war. Both these projects are being considered for funding by the Government as part of the Government's program to mark the International Year of Peace, l986. It may be of interest for honourable members to know that a resolution was adopted at the latest session of the United Nations General Assembly, which Australia supported, which requests the Secretary-General to compile and distribute as a document of the United Nations appropriate excerpts of all national and international scientific studies on the climatic effects of nuclear war, including nuclear winter, published so far or which may be published before 3l July l985. This compilation of studies is to be examined at the next General Assembly meeting in l985 in connection with the item dealing with the prevention of nuclear war. Australia will be making a contribution to this compilation of studies based on research carried out by Australian scientists in this area, including those of CSIRO. Finally, the question of nuclear winter has been considered in a number of non-government meetings in Australia in recent years.
—I don't think you even understand what you are saying.
—I feel sorry for the honourable member. He was born rather dull and I have news for him: He has been going steadily backwards ever since.
—Tell us about the drover's dog.

—If it were a cat the honourable member would know more about it, I understand. The question of nuclear winter has been considered in a number of non-government meetings in Australia in recent years, notably the symposium at the Australian National University in 1983 on the effects of nuclear war and the biennial meeting of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science in l984.

—My question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, relates to the forthcoming taxation summit. Can the honourable gentleman inform the House when invitations to the taxation summit will be issued? When will the Government's White Paper on taxation be issued? Finally, will the White Paper indicate the Government's preferred option for taxation reform or will it merely restate the differing and, indeed, antagonistic views within the Australian Labor Party on that subject?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad that the honourable member asked the question about invitations because I was fascinated to see in this morning's Press that in this division-ridden Liberal Party that we have in Australia-

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I can understand that there is a certain amount of hilarity and reaction on occasions such as this. However, it can go too far. I invite honourable members to remain quiet.

—As on so many other matters in respect of which Liberals are so divided, they seem to be divided on the question of tax and whether they should go to the summit or not. I see that the meeting that they had down in Melbourne, which, admittedly, did not get quite the coverage that another meeting did, passed a resolution that they should attend the tax summit. What do we make of these people? We have the Leader of the Liberal Party saying: 'No way; we will not go'. Then we have his Victorian Branch saying: 'Yes, we should go'. So, we will be sending honourable members opposite an invitation. We hope that they in fact have the good sense to play, at long last, a constructive role in Australian politics, that instead of their perpetual negativism they will come along and constructively say what should happen in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: We look forward to having honourable members opposite there. I will be in the chair and I assure them that they will get the call. Invitations will be issued, I think, within the week. The finalisation of the White Paper is going ahead now. I would expect-I say this subject to correction-that the White Paper would be issued so that those going to the summit would have it for approximately a month beforehand and thus have a very good opportunity to examine it.

The third part of the honourable member's question asked whether we would be asserting the position of the Government. I understand his asking this, because it has been evident over many years that those opposite are slow learners. It is surprising, however, that they have not yet got the message on this matter. I repeat, in the hope-perhaps vain-that on this occasion they might get the message, that the Government, in its White Paper, will have a number of alternative packages setting out possible ways of dealing with the existing inadequacies of this country's taxation system. We shall not go to that summit with a closed mind, saying: 'This is the position. We have made up our minds'.

I have made it quite clear that we want to hear the views of those at the summit. Fortunately, as distinct from those with closed and/or empty minds on the other side of this House, it has been made clear by those who wish to come to the summit that they have very much to contribute and they want to do so in a constructive way. This Government will pay them the courtesy, the tribute and the honour of listening intently to what they have to say. Out of the processes of the summit this Government will do as I have always said it will do, namely, accept the ultimate responsibility of making the decisions in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aviation. I draw his attention to recent Press reports that in future the Government will require investment in airports to be on a sound commercial basis. Are these reports correct? If so, what action is being taken to implement this policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the reports, which generally are correct. The House should recognise that there is a huge public investment in airports and airport infrastructure. It follows that that investment should be used efficiently. It should maximise economic performance so that we get all the revenues we can, in terms of commercial opportunities that could exist at airports and around airports, at the same time as we minimise expenditure. If airports are not managed on an efficient commercial basis, the losses incurred by the infrastructure eventually feed into aviation cost recovery. We inherited from those opposite a deficit of $200m per annum on the provision of aviation infrastructure services. If it is not met there, the loss feeds into the fare structure. Every airport developed on the basis that it cannot pay its own way will eventually result in the forcing up of domestic air fares.

ANSWER.PARA: Those opposite reached the stage where, in the dishing out of airport promises, one could recognise the old cry made by, I think, a former member for Wakefield who used to say: 'There must be an election in the air. I can feel a dam coming on'. That was changed very astutely by those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —One did not come on in Tasmania.
—It is all right for you. All right?
—You are just a yapper.
—That is the way it breaks. Yep, yep, yep yep, yep! Do you feel better now?

—Order! When one is in the chair one has to make a judgment about what is good natured-repartee and what is not. I have accepted that the exchange between the Minister and the honourable member for Franklin was one of a good-natured kind but I ask them to desist.

—It came to the stage under the Government of those who now sit opposite that the word 'airport' was substituted for the word 'dam' and we could say: 'I am sure there is an election in the air because I can feel an airport coming on'. That cargo cult approach to airport investment had to be stopped. No one better than the Deputy Leader of the Opposition recognises that. He is the man who says that the deficit has to be reduced, that government expenditure must come down. He understands that very well. I know that he lectures his colleagues on that issue. If we do not have a wise program of airport investment it means that we starve those airports of essential upgrading. One excellent example of that and of the achievements of those opposite is Townsville Airport. If ever there was an airport facility that was inadequate and below standard it is Townsville's domestic terminal. Why is it that way? It is because in the past money has been pumped into monuments for politicians rather than into services infrastructure for the passengers who use the air services. That situation has to change. There has to be a much more commercial approach to the development of airports and much more rigorous economic discipline in respect of airport investment. We will be asking: Is the airport expansion needed? Who is going to use it? Who is going to pay for it? If we are to have lower taxes, lower deficits and reductions in government expenditure, airports is one area at which we have to look. That brings me to the issue of Darwin Airport.
—What about the Prime Minister's promise?

—What about the honourable member's promise? If ever there was a legacy left to an unfortunate Chief Minister it is the legacy that has been left to Chief Minister Tuxworth in the Northern Territory. If we look at honourable members opposite and the former Chief Minister of the Territory, we say: 'What did they do about Darwin Airport?'. I can tell honourable members what they did. They managed to keep the World War II hangar, with its bullet holes in the roof, in service for 40 years. That is a great achievement! They did nothing about giving Darwin a new airport other than to make promises and to break them. I have waited here in vain, week after week, day after day, for the honourable member for Murray, the honourable member for the Northern Territory and the Leader of the National Party of Australia to ask me a question about Darwin Airport; but no, there has not been a question. The honourable member for Herbert has recognised the problem that we have inherited with respect to airport investment and asked a question. I thank him for the opportunity to answer, because the people of the Territory need better airport facilities than they have received from the 30 years of government by the conservative parties.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had to defer the letting of any further contracts at Darwin Airport. Even though $8m to $llm has been spent up there already-we are probably locked into $llm-if we go beyond the existing contracts we will be in for another $90m. If one considers that Darwin Airport involves an investment overall of $l00m plus and that it handles fewer passengers than Townsville Airport--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Canberra Airport.

—Well fewer than Canberra, yes. If we take the investment at only l0 per cent we are looking at a $20 per passenger impost just to service the investment at Darwin Airport. We have had to look at the matter again. The threshold question is: Should the new facility and terminal be built on a site other than the existing site? That threshold decision of earlier years has to be looked at again. We need to look at options for a lesser-standard facility. As I have said, airports ought to be functional for passengers, not monuments to politicians, as we saw happening under conservative governments. We will be looking at that in respect of the Darwin question. There have been discussions in respect of Darwin between myself and the Minister for Defence. As soon as I am in a position to announce a decision in respect of further activity there I will do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aviation and concerns a related aspect of aviation, namely, safety. Is the Minister aware of the varying degrees of operational capability of radar systems at Australia's major airports, particularly at Sydney, due to the antiquated nature of much of the equipment. Is he further aware that where there is more modern equipment, at Perth, showing automatically the height of aircraft, a Department of Aviation instruction exists saying that controllers must ignore the accurate heights shown? What action is the Minister taking to upgrade radar standards in the interests of aviation safety and to review that instruction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It follows directly from what I was saying just a few moments ago. There is a deficiency in the technical facilities for aircraft movement within Australia because the Department of Aviation has been starved of money in order that monuments to National Party Ministers could be built.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite might not like the answer but they are going to cop it. The Department has been starved of money to put into essential technical capital infrastructure works, which primarily concerns radar-radar investments and the updating of radar equipment. Presently the program being followed, with the limited funds that are available, is such that we are replacing the oldest facilities first. That is why Perth is getting more modern equipment before, for instance, Sydney. But the equipment that is being replaced in Perth is much older than that in use in Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: What am I doing about it? I am doing what I just explained a while ago. I am deferring action on Darwin Airport as part of my approach to tackling the overall problem of trying to contain expenditure, to find the resources to put into what I see as essential investment, to make the system work more efficiently and, most of all, to make it safer. If the honourable member's colleagues whom he has now joined had followed a similar course in earlier years, he would not have needed to ask the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am about to ask my first question of the Minister for Aviation. Am I to understand that it is the Government's intention to run airports on a commercial basis? If so, is it the Government's intention to publish and debate a cost-benefit analysis before deciding on a second airport for Sydney rather than the much more rational extension of Kingsford-Smith Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question.
—You're sorry you started them now, aren't you.

—No, I am not sorry that I started them now. I am pleased that I started them now. It is the Government's intention, wherever possible, to place the management of airports on a much more businesslike and commercial basis. They represent a major investment for the Australian people. They have not been operated on a commercial basis. Opportunities for revenue gathering and for improved efficiency and productivity have not been taken in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: The major means that we will be following to achieve that objective in respect of the principal airports will be the establishment of a national airports authority. We are well down the track in the preparation of the initial work for the establishment of the authority. We will certainly be looking at the proposal put forward by the honourable member for Prospect. He asked whether we really need a second Sydney airport if we are to operate the existing investment on a commercial basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he really meant a second runway at Kingsford-Smith.

—I did not know that I had so many advisers in this place. Perhaps we should have a meeting when Question Time is over. I would appreciate the honourable member's advice. We are in the process of preparing for the authority. The method of operation and the management of the airports will be the same. We will put them on a much more businesslike basis than was experienced under the administration of those who now sit opposite. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE: AUSTRALIA'S DIPLOMATIC REPRESENTATION IN AFRICA AND ADJACENT ISLAND STATES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to have this opportunity to respond to the report of the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee concerning Australia's diplomatic representation in Africa and adjacent Indian Ocean island states. I appreciate that the Committee, and particularly its Sub-Committee on Middle Eastern and African Affairs, has found time to give attention to this important aspect of Australia's relations with Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I took up the Foreign Affairs portfolio, I have been concerned to ensure that my Department's resources are deployed in a manner consistent with Australia's national interests. As regards Africa, this has meant a readjustment in diplomatic representation to reflect the fact that Australia's relations with and interests in Africa lie predominantly, though not exclusively, in east Africa, the Horn and southern Africa. In this respect my views coincide with those of the Committee.

The House will also be aware of my concern to develop Australia's relations with its Indian Ocean neighbours. In January 1984, the Government adopted guidelines for a comprehensive and integrated Australian policy approach to Indian Ocean issues based on recognition of Australia's interests in the region and its status as an Indian Ocean littoral state. Under these guidelines the Australian Government seeks to give greater attention to the development of relations with Indian Ocean island countries and, to a lesser extent, East African states. I am pleased to note that the Committee's report is in line with these objectives.

The Committee has made three major recommendations concerning Australia's diplomatic representation in Africa and the Indian Ocean. The Government has already implemented two of those recommendations. In January 1984, the Government approved the opening of a resident High Commission in Mauritius, and the post has been in operation since March 1984. The High Commission is accredited to Seychelles, Comoros and it is intended that it will be accredited to Madagascar. It will be the focal point for Australia's bilateral and regional policies concerning the Indian Ocean island states.

Following the 1984-85 Budget discussions the Government approved the opening of a post in Addis Ababa. The post was established in December 1984. This decision recognised the strategic importance of Ethiopia in the Horn of Africa, Ethiopia's role as host to the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa and the Organisation of African Unity, and the value of having a resident diplomatic presence to deal more effectively with the Ethiopian Government and relief agencies in meeting both the short and longer term problems arising from the tragic famine affecting the region. It has been possible to open the additional posts in Africa, the Indian Ocean and Budapest as a result of the reassessment of the actual and prospective operations and purposes of all our missions.

The decision to close the High Commission in Accra was not easy. Australia values its good relationship with Ghana and has no wish to give the impression that it is not concerned with or interested in the issues of the area. I have assured the Ghanaian Government that Australia looks forward to maintaining close relations though the accreditation of a non-resident High Commissioner.

The opening of a new mission in Addis Ababa-the seat of the OAU and the ECA-demonstrates the Australian Government's continuing interest in Africa. The implications of the Accra closure, together with the question of our representation in the Francophone countries, will be kept under review. These decisions are the result of a rigorous reassessment of the overall functioning of our overseas posts. This reassessment is continuing generally, though it has not yet reached any conclusive stage.

I conclude by once again thanking the Committee for its useful and relevant report. I believe the Committee is to be congratulated on the work it has performed in recent years on Africa, which has complemented the Government's own consideration of Australian relations with this region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement is welcomed by the Opposition, but only as far as the statement goes. We are very disappointed that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) today has not taken the opportunity given to him to outline the Government's attitudes and the effect of the implementation of its policy in this very difficult and sensitive area of the world. It seems to me that there was a perfect opportunity today for the Minister to deal with some of the great problems of the area under discussion. I am glad that the Minister has complimented yet again the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on its role in bringing forward reports of this nature. As we all know, the Joint Standing Committee over a long period of years has had the reputation of looking at these problems in great detail and coming up with sound and sensible suggestions. I am glad that the Government has seen fit to adopt many of the recommendations contained in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Minister has failed to do today is to outline the Government's views on what it perceives as Australia's role in regard to the long-term solution of many of the problems in this area of the world. He has failed to mention what the needs of the area are. One perhaps would have thought he could have mentioned the need for more indigenous production of agricultural food crops. This is, of course, a matter of tremendous concern not only to voluntary agencies throughout the world, including Australia, but also to many of the government agencies involved in this problem.

Surely the Minister does not feel that by opening up a few diplomatic posts the long term needs of the people in the region will be solved. We must not forget that what prompted the Sub-Committee to inquire into diplomatic representation in Africa was the allegation of misappropriations in Ethiopia. Unfortunately, the Minister in his statement today has not reassured the Parliament or the people of Australia that there will be no more examples of Australian aid to Eritrea being commandeered by the Ethiopian Government as was recently the case. Obviously, the Australian taxpayers and the overseas aid agencies need to know that the organisation of Australian relief is of a high standard and this can be done only through some positive action by this Government-positive action which, I am afraid, is conspicuous by its absence.

As I have already mentioned, the problems of Ethiopia are of tremendous concern to us all. In fact the coalition views with very great concern the stories filtering out of Ethiopia and this led to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) visiting that country late last year. He reported to the International Democratic Union that what was occurring was a famine of potentially catastrophic proportions. It is a result of poor rains, poor soil, poor water management, overcultivation and deforestation. The effects of all this have been exacerbated by foolish and short-sighted government policies in the area. The Minister, by ignoring the opportunity given to him today, has shown that the Government has an insular approach to the region. Of course we do not need to look any further than the Government's approach to the problems of the Middle East; it has decided to withdraw Australia's peacekeeping forces from the Sinai even against the advice and the wishes of the two governments involved-those of Egypt and Israel. This inept decision was taken even though Egypt and Israel expressly asked this Government to keep the forces there.

Of course that decision was the Government's response to factional pressures within the Australian Labor Party. It is amazing how many issues come back to a factional dispute within the Labor Party. I do not need to remind anybody in this House of the appalling scenes which were the order of the day in Victoria over the weekend, where 'Tomato Flavoured Labor Bloodbath' was the headline in some of the newspapers. I am sure that Community Aid Abroad and other organisations which have workers in this area of the world to which the Committee has addressed itself would have liked to hear more from the Minister on what future assistance will be given to the area and where the Australian Government sees its future direction.

As I have said, as far as the Minister's statement goes, it is fine; but it did not go very far at all. It is important to recognise that Australia is a two-ocean continent which needs independent diplomatic representation. I, like many other members of this place, have been concerned at the inadequacy of the information we sometimes receive on current trends in countries overseas, and the reorganisation of our representation, hopefully, will do something to improve that situation. Obviously many benefits will accrue to Australia and its people by the rearrangements that have been made to our posts in Africa and adjacent areas. As I have said, I hope that this will enable members of this Parliament to be provided with up-to-date information on the area.

The statement does not go very far at all. It is not constructive about the longer term issues confronting the area. It is a benign statement which adds nothing whatsoever to our store of information. The only thing that can be said about it in its favour is that it does pick up some of the recommendations in the report of the Sub-Committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. In that sense it is to be welcomed; but it is to be deplored because of its inadequacy of research, its inadequacy of new material and its inadequacy in presenting a long term solution, as the Government sees it, to these problems in this part of the world.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The effect on the family farm and all Australian farmers of the failure of the Government to contain the cost-price crisis facing agricultural industries.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter of public importance in the knowledge that tonight the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) once again meet the National Farmers Federation to discuss the cost-price crisis facing Australian farmers. Prior to the last election the Prime Minister gave an undertaking that a summit conference would be held with the representatives of the rural industries to discuss the cost-price squeeze facing farmers and affecting the terms of trade of agriculture. Unfortunately, the recent get-together with the National Farmers Federation proved to be an abortive exercise because of a dispute between the Government and the NFF regarding the basis upon which the Federation had calculated the cost of the tariff to agricultural export industries. A working party has since been thrashing around in an attempt to find an agreed basis for assessing the cost of tariff protection to the agricultural export industries. No doubt a new figure has been found less than the $19,000 per farm originally submitted by the NFF-a figure established upon information which was provided by the Industries Assistance Commission and information which, as I understand it, was used to calculate the cost of tariff protection.
—Is that $19,000 a farm?

—Yes, indeed. But it does not matter how the Government representatives play around with the figures; the truth is that the terms of trade per farmer have been declining for years. I do not totally blame the Hawke Labor Government for the problem-I think that it would be wrong to do that-but I do blame the Hawke Labor Government for an acceleration of that decline, which is increasing as the Hawke Government withdraws support for agriculture and its level of protection declines faster than for other sectors of the economy. The decline in terms of trade is averaging about 2.4 per cent per annum. While the overall level of effective protection for secondary industries has declined from 36 per cent to 25 per cent since 1972-73, its has fallen twice as fast for agriculture, from an estimated 28 per cent to 8 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I recently obtained the most up to date figures that I could obtain from the Industries Assistance Commission on the net subsidy equivalent per employee expressed in dollars for a few selected heavily protected industries. They make interesting reading. For instance, the net subsidy equivalent per employee for the footwear industry until l982 was $l6,388 per annum; for the passenger motor vehicle industry it was $l6,587 per annum; for the clothing industry it was $l5,l56; while for the dairy industry, which is so often depicted as the most heavily protected industry, it was $6,824 per annum.

I mention these facts because there is a perception that farmers generally have been heavily subsidised and protected. This perception is not correct for many of the export industries in the agricultural sector. I name the wool industry, the meat industry and the grains industry and I could go on naming a whole host of industries. Of course, some of them have to receive protection because of the degree to which they have to compete with subsidised export surpluses which are dumped from countries that oversubsidise their agricultural industries. I refer to the European Economic Community.

I am not making a plea for protection or subsidies. Both forms of assistance over the years have weakened the vitality, efficiency and competitiveness of industries where they have been extensively used. There are grounds for short term and emergency assistance in special circumstances; however, prolonged industry assistance not only causes a misallocation of resources but ultimately weakens an industry's ability to operate with efficiency and to compete for markets. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the clothing, footwear and textile industries.

However, it is essential to be even-handed in dealing with protectionism or reducing assistance. It is no use advocating the application of free market forces unless those forces apply to every sector of the economy, including the wages sector. Unfortunately, the Hawke Government has not carried forward its rational, economic approach in freeing up the financial and exchange system to the wages policy area. Most members on this side of the House support that approach and have given public support to it following the tabling in this Parliament by our Government of the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, a report that was commissioned by the then Treasurer, the Hon. John Howard. On the one hand we have a free financial and exchange rate system, the proposed dismantling of the pooling system for dairy products and the lack of short term assistance for the sugar industry. But these industries are suffering because the competing world market is absolutely flooded with surplus subsidised products from some of our competing nations. On the other hand we have the assistance for the steel division of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and a centralised, institutionalised, inflexible indexed wage fixation system that gives special financial privilege to the real master of this Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. This inconsistent, one-eyed, lopsided policy can only damage the export industries which have to compete on hard fought world markets.

The agricultural industries remain the most important of the export sectors of the Australian economy. The farmers account for between 35 per cent and 50 per cent of Australia's export earnings, depending on seasonal conditions. At a time when we require increasing export revenue to pay our fast growing foreign debt-now standing at about $60 billion-agricultural profitability becomes all the more important to the national well-being. The honeymoon is over for Australia. We are going to be put to the test in international competition as never before. The honeymoon is over for the Hawke Labor Government. The honeymoon is over for the honourable member for Werriwa, the Minister for Primary Industry. The Ministry must respond to the case being put by the National Farmers Federation. The Minister must accept that. The depressed condition of agriculture is being exacerbated by high inflation relative to world prices.

A record high in real interest rates is eroding the ability of agriculture to compete and this very important fact must not be avoided. Interest rates are high in real terms-I think that they are amongst the highest in the world. Since l980-8l our terms of trade have fallen by 2l per cent while those of the United States have fallen by only 10 per cent. Our inflation rate is nearly twice that of the United States.

The breaking of the drought in l983 and the massive increase in farm returns from a low base following three to four years of drought gave the unfortunate perception that farmers' problems were over. Nothing could have been further from the truth. Australia's farmers and their families are in real difficulties. In some industries they are worse off than in others. However, thousands of farming families are living on incomes that are well below the poverty level. For instance, 30 per cent of growers in the sugar industry are facing economic disaster. In the dairy industry 5,000 to 6,000 producers will have to leave the industry if the present Kerin plan is implemented without amendment. There are serious problems facing dried fruit growers, the vine industry, the wine industry and the rice industry. The jaws of the cost-price vice have gripped the efficient wheat and grain industries.

The main area in which the Hawke Labor Government can assist producers is that of farm costs. There is little that the Government can do to improve world commodity prices, but there are areas where the Hawke Government can assist in reducing the burden of costs. An across-the-board cut in tariffs to reduce the extended protection being afforded by the devaluation in import competing industries could be applied immediately. The National Farmers Federation has sought a 10 per cent reduction.

The Government could extend immediate help in other areas. It could abolish export inspection charges, which are not payable by agricultural exporters in competing countries. It could replace the l5 per cent tariff on imported headers with a bounty, thus removing a $l2m to $l4m burden from farmers' pockets to protect 260 jobs in a farm machinery company in Victoria. I cannot give a better example of the way in which the farmers of this country involved in the grain industry have been exploited by this type of cost. It is no good the Minister or the Prime Minister talking in sympathetic terms about farmers' problems when in fact they continue to ignore the imposition of this burden on the pockets of farmers. We do not mind seeing 260 jobs protected in Victoria, but they should be protected at the community's expense and not, as is being done in this case, at the farmers' expense. There should also be a reduction in government expenditure and low Budget deficits, as well as a reduction in the level of interest rates. The wage fixation system should be replaced with a more flexible system. There should also be an immediate restoration of the full off-road diesel fuel rebate-the Government is robbing the farmers of this country of $25m to $30m in a sneaky way.

The declining terms of trade for agriculture-that is, the ratio of prices received to prices paid-is now standing at about 2 per cent to 2.4 per cent. It will be claimed, of course, that the devaluation of the Australian dollar will help to overcome the problem. It will give some short term assistance to some industries, notably the beef and wool industries; however, unless this Government supports discounting the indexed wage fixation system for the devaluation there will be further serious inflationary problems ahead for export industries, in fact for the Australian community. Unless the tariff is adjusted for the 2l per cent devaluation there will be a further surge in critical input costs next financial year. In spite of the devaluation, the gross farmer product at constant l979-80 prices is expected to fall by 4 per cent in l985-86. If the inflationary effects of this devaluation flow on in wages increases, there is no doubt that our agricultural export industries will be further disadvantaged by increased inflation and a further drop in our competitiveness.

The Australian farmers and their families are becoming increasingly restless over this Government's failure to match its rhetoric with action. Australia's l70,000 farms contribute more than $ll billion to gross domestic product every year. Australian farm industries are world leaders in efficiency and rural output has more than trebled since the early l950s. Yet, today, these industries face perhaps their greatest ever crisis. They are locked in the jaws of a cost-price vice which is accelerating the decline of their international competitiveness. In the late l970s these industries were plunged headlong into one of the worst droughts ever experienced. In l982-83, farm income per work year of family labour fell below zero. On average, there was simply no net income to families.

Despite this, the primary industries showed their typical resilience and relatively few producers were forced off their properties. Of course, this was due to the policies of the Fraser Government during that drought. However, there is now a threat of a further drought in much of eastern Australia. In spite of the breaking of the earlier drought, income per work year of family labour remains below $l0,000 a year and continues to fall. Current predictions suggest that it will fall to about $7,000. This Labor Government has failed to act decisively to reduce farm costs. It has turned around and attacked these industries in the blind hope that its rhetoric about concern for farm industries will blanket the real impact of its decisions.

The Minister was reported earlier today to have said that farm costs had risen at a slower rate in the last few years than during the term of the previous Government. He made no mention of Australia's inflation rate, relative to world rates, which was significantly less than the international level for a large part of the Fraser Government's period of office, but remains above those of many major competitors. He made no mention of changes in world commodity prices. As primary producers over a wide area of Australia face the prospect of another crushing drought, they cannot do so with any confidence because of the disgraceful way in which the Government has treated the rural community.

The economy of the country is out of kilter when, as land prices in some areas clearly indicate, the price of the land and the farm itself far exceed its earning capacity. This has been so for a long time. This is not something new which has occurred under the Hawke Labor Government; it has been so for a long time and it is something which has been argued for a long time under previous conservative governments. It is part of the system at present. The honourable member, who came in here bleating about issues causing problems on the land, will see, if he goes out and looks at the real world, that most of the problems are caused, first of all, by land prices being far in excess of the earning capacity of that land. A farmer in difficulty in the three industries I mentioned previously would have serious difficulty at the moment if he were paying interest rates on land that was too dear in the first place.

I move on to consider some other on-farm costs. Let us look at fuel costs. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates an increase of 293 per cent-nearly 300 per cent, as the Minister said-in fuel costs since September l975. Who was in charge from September l975 on? Malcolm Fraser and his Government were in control through that period.

We also hear, of course, of the terrible problem of wages. Wages increased by some 50 per cent under Malcolm Fraser over that short period. I will not stand here and say that wages have gone up by only a certain percentage under the Hawke Labor Government. I am saying that under the Hawke Labor Government wages have gone up at a rate similar to that under the Fraser Government and that they reflect the economic management of the country. Under the Hawke Labor Government the worker has had only an ll per cent wage increase, but he is willing to accept that ll per cent increase because of the better economic management of the economy that is reflected in that increase.

The reason we had massive increases in costs in the period of the Fraser Government was that it was that Government's philosophy that each industry should go out and bargain on its strength. That is the National Party approach. That Party believes that we should grind what we can out of the market while we can. I must admit that the rural sector has learnt that philosophy from experience. Get the maximum out of the market this year because, in the export world, we may not get as much next year. When that philosophy was imposed on the wages sector we had industries in Australia which had the capacity to pay. Like any good union leader in Australia, the rural producer said: 'These are the rules; this is what the Government says we abide by: Let's do what the National Party always does-let's get out of the market what we can'.

In some industries in Australia we had enormous wage increases simply because they were the rules of play. This did not always flow through to every person in the community, though. Some people in the community did not have the strength to go out and get that wage increase. As inflation expanded, of course, these people did not retain their buying capacity. That affects the rural sector as much as any other sector, because we then have a depression. That depression that the Fraser Government's economic policy created has had a bigger impact on the rural sector than anything this Government has done in the last l8 months to two years. I refute the arguments put forward here today by members of the Opposition when they say that the cost-price squeeze is anything other than an ongoing fact of history. We are taking better measures at this stage to overcome that problem.

The protection debate is a valid one. We do not argue against the claim that there is a cost against the exporting sectors when we have high protection for some industries. Which Government introduced the new motor vehicle package? Which Government introduced the new steel industry plan? Is the National Party suggesting that we do not want a manufacturing base in Australia? Can honourable members imagine the outcry from the old Country Party leader, old Black Jack McEwen, if he had heard some of the arguments put forward today? The manufacturing base in Australia is a very important base. I can assure honourable members that there are not too many people in the farming sector who would honestly believe that they could afford to do away with that manufacturing base.

When we had the 25 per cent protection cut by the Whitlam Government the farmers benefited, although we would not think so. I do not think that in any period of Australia's history more has been done in one stroke to assist the farming sector and less support has been received for that assistance from anybody in the rural sector than at that time. This is why this Government is now going for specific industry packages. We cannot afford to have just one industry versus another in the protection argument. Industry protection has to be done on the basis of our looking at specific industries and working the problem through. This means that we have to look at the sugar industry, the dairy industry and the dried fruits industry on a similar basis. If we are going to have economic rationale this cannot apply to one industry and not to others. I say to this Parliament that the Government knows exactly where it is going. It is putting the economy on the right path, and I believe the record is on the board to show that.
