TALK.START.PARA: —The National Welfare Fund Repeal Bill l985 has been brought forward as a result of the Auditor-General's report of l98l and the action that was commenced after that by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle when she was the Minister for Finance. By way of background, the National Welfare Fund was established by the National Welfare Fund Act l943 as the vehicle for making various welfare or social service payments as were directed by any law of the Commonwealth to be made from the Fund. Initially the amounts paid into the Fund were provided from general revenue. In l945 the Parliament passed the Social Services Contribution Act and the Payroll Tax Act to provide revenue, specifically earmarked by virtue of a complementary amendment to the National Welfare Fund Act, which appropriated the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the purpose of the National Welfare Fund. In l950 the social services contribution was merged with income taxation. The National Welfare Fund Act was amended to ensure that the income of the National Welfare Fund would be approximately the same as if the social services contribution had remained a separate levy. The lack of real nexus between the earmarked revenue of the National Welfare Fund and the payments from it resulted in a substantial buildup in the Fund's credit balance.

SPEECH.PARA: In l952 Parliament amended the National Welfare Fund Act to provide that future payments from Consolidated Revenue to the Fund would in any financial year be equal to the amounts paid out for welfare and social purposes. A standing appropriation from Consolidated Revenue was provided to enable the payments to be made into the National Welfare Fund. The balance then standing to the credit of the Welfare Fund, some $750m, was recycled within the Commonwealth public account by investment in internal Treasury bills-that is, by transferring moneys from the trust fund of which the National Welfare Fund is a part to the loan fund, to the extent necessary to cover any temporary revenue deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The procedure whereby a temporary shortfall in revenue of the Consolidated Revenue may be met by payments from the loan fund is authorised by the Loan (Temporary Revenue Deficits) Act l953. Interest received on such investments increased the National Welfare Fund's balance to some $450m by l976, at which point the then Treasurer announced that the Government had decided that the balance should be repaid to the Consolidated Revenue Fund pursuant to section 62A of the Audit Act. Since that time there has been no continuing balance in the National Welfare Fund. All expenditure from it has been precisely matched by payments into it from Consolidated Revenue pursuant to the standing appropriation inserted in the National Welfare Fund Act l952, as amended.

The raison d'etre for the National Welfare Fund, namely, as a vehicle for the receipt of specifically earmarked revenue levies, pending their disbursement for welfare and social security payments, was effectively removed in l952 when the earmarked revenues were replaced through an amendment to the National Welfare Fund Act via general revenue payments to the National Welfare Fund which previously matched the expenditures from it. The Auditor-General, in his report on the financial statements prepared by the Minister for Finance for the year ended 30 June l98l and upon other accounts, stated that he had sought the views of the Department of Finance as to whether it would be appropriate to seek the amendments to the National Welfare Fund Act and complementary legislation to abolish the Fund, as he considered that it served no useful function either as a control mechanism or as a holding account for future expenditure. He stated:
Its continuation as the hub of the accounting process entails significant and unnecessary accounting work.

As reflected in the Auditor-General's report, the Department of Finance replied that the question of the abolition of the National Welfare Fund had been under notice for some time. The reply indicated that the National Welfare Fund is now no more than a channel through which certain welfare payments are made and that it facilitates neither the recording, transacting nor accounting of such payments. As such, the Fund is an anachronism and superfluous. There are quite a few things in that category.

Payments from the National Welfare Fund require daily matching payments to the Fund for the standing appropriation of Consolidated Revenue under the National Welfare Fund Act. This involves a significant burden on spending departments and the Department of Finance, in processing more than 5,000 journal entries a year between the Consolidated Revenue Fund and the National Welfare Fund and effectively corresponding the reconciliation process. There is, of course, a similar audit burden. The National Welfare Fund process in regard to the standing appropriation does not result in any greater degree of control or accountability than if welfare and social security payments were made direct from the separate standing appropriations under the legislation which authorises the payments. Indeed, the control over individual types of welfare and social security payments can be complicated by having to operate through the Welfare Fund.

The superfluous journal entries necessary in the present system, together with the associated reconciliations, are demanding on the staff and resources. The final expenditure process is, of course, essential and identical, whichever alternative is used. It is also, effectively, largely processed through the Department of Finance's computerised cheque writing, conciliation and ledger system. The journal entry process under the National Welfare Fund system is, of course, spread over the full year and is shared among three departments-Social Security, Health and Housing and Construction. The Department of Finance and the Auditor-General's Office are also involved, but to a lesser extent. One is also doubtful as to whether the abolition of the National Welfare Fund would enable significant, if any, staff savings. It would remove an ineffective administrative process and enable a far more effective utilisation of present staff resources. The Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the National Welfare Fund Repeal Bill l985, I am cognisant of the historical connections that our actions today have with those of the wartime Curtin Government. It was that Government which introduced the National Welfare Fund Bill of l943 to provide finance for a number of social security benefits, including initiatives for maternity allowances, funeral benefits for pensioners and a sustenance allowance for the dependants of invalid pensioners. When we look at that Bill of l943, a number of principles embodied in the legislation of the day maintain their relevance today. The benefits were available to all. It was felt at the time that the social stigma certainly felt by people at the lower end of the spectrum needed to be addressed at the time. Certainly one aspect that comes to mind is the provision for funeral benefits for pensioners, because of the social stigma that was attached at the time to people having a pauper's funeral. When one reads the speeches of l943 and looks at the words that were used in those days, one can see that the overriding social conscience of the then Government was to make sure that that social stigma, to the largest extent possible, was alleviated.

SPEECH.PARA: Another principle was the ability to pay. Of course, by paying the benefit out of Consolidated Revenue it was taken from all taxpayers. However, some of the benefits up to that time relied on private contributions, and people who were at the lower end of the socio-economic scale of the day could not afford them. While I was reading some old speeches I came across a speech by a Mr Pollard, who was in 1943 the honourable member for Ballarat. He had this to say about the Bill:
Behind all the opposition to this bill is the fact that the tax by which the necessary funds are to be raised is to be levied in accordance with the taxpayers' ability to pay.

If we bring our minds back to l983 when this Government brought in Medicare we will see that the very same principle applied. We recognised that the ability to pay should not be the principle by which people receive medical treatment. It should not be based on the fact that some people can pay more than others. If we adopt that principle we will be looking at people who will receive better treatment than others for their medical condition solely because they are wealthier. Another significant fact is that the Opposition of the day proposed a flat levy in exactly the same way as the medical system required prior to Medicare.

A second feature of the Bill of the day was that the money that was not expended was invested for the future. That was a radical departure for the government of the day. It indicated to me that that Government was willing to look further into the future, certainly more so than governments which have followed it. I will speak briefly on the relevance of that to the age pension. The Superannuation Act 1943 in some ways was the embryo of a national superannuation scheme; it certainly had some significant points going for it. If this scheme had continued we may today have had a national superannuation scheme instead of the age pension system. In l974, 5.75 million people in Australia were in civil employment and 29 per cent of those had access to a superannuation fund of one kind or another. Thus honourable members can see that the provision of superannuation entitlements is not universal in Australia. It was not in l974 and it certainly is not now and that is something that needs addressing.

An Australian study on superannuation showed a great imbalance. This private study covered 583 private businesses within Australia. Fifty-six per cent of the males in those businesses were covered by superannuation, whereas only 22 per cent of the women were covered; so there was a great imbalance. There was also a great imbalance according to which end of the spectrum one worked at. For example, 9l per cent of the executives, 72 per cent of salaried people and only 32 per cent of the workers had access to superannuation. Certainly the proponents of the l943 Bill were very much more aware of the age spread than were the governments which followed them. Australia does have an aging population. I am sure that what was in the mind of the Government in l943 when it brought in the National Welfare Fund Bill was that services for the aging population would have to rely on investing money for the future rather than paying it, as we do now, from taxes collected in the year in which benefits are paid.

In l88l only 2.5 per cent of the population was over 65. By l98l, l00 years later, that figure had risen to l0 per cent; and, if we project into the future to the year 200l, in excess of l2 per cent of the population will be over 65. The fundamentals of the l943 National Welfare Fund Bill should be addressed again in this place when we start to look at social security provisions for the future.

In l938 the conservative Treasurer of the day, Mr Casey, was concerned at the cost of pensions and made a 40-year projection. In that year he predicted that in 40 years there would be l.28 million pensioners. In actual fact there were l.38 million pensioners. So his prediction was fairly close; he was within 2 per cent. He predicted that the cost of those pensions in l978 dollars would be $476m but in actual fact it amounted to $3,229m. So when he came to estimating the cost to revenue of those pensions he was out by a massive 680 per cent. That gives honourable members an idea of the sorts of figures we are working with. Once again I go back to the principle involved in the National Welfare Fund Bill l943 of investing money so that in the future we can draw on money that people have earned in the past and that money will build up into a significant amount so that we can afford real benefits for people as they retire. We should also be able to afford social security provisions for welfare people as they need them.

Another point about that Bill was that it was opposed by the conservatives of the day. However, that is nothing new. Just about every major reform that the Australian Labor Party has brought into this House has been opposed by them at one time or another. So in that regard nothing has changed. We are coming up for another reform this year. As we all know, the tax system is long overdue for reform. We will see how the Opposition plays its cards on that one. In Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave us a fairly good indication of how we should view that. When speaking on the National Welfare Fund Bill Mr Morgan, who was the then honourable member for Reid, had this to say about the Opposition's tactics:
When it was proposed 30 years ago to establish the Commonwealth Bank the argument advanced against it was that it was a 'phoney scheme' and a 'confidence trick'.

Some other terms used by Opposition members to describe the National Welfare Fund Bill l933 were 'Frankenstein monster', 'nebulous and hollow sham', 'fundamentally unsound', 'fantastic', 'too visionary', 'a wildcat scheme', 'the time is not right' and 'a confidence trick'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never learn.

—The conservative parties never learn; they are still saying the same things today. It will be very interesting when the tax reform comes up because to see the back of a Liberal one has only to mention the word 'reform'. A sniff of reform in the air and the Liberals are gone. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has already said that if he were given an invitation to the tax summit he would not attend.
—They are very worried.

—I think they should be worried because the Liberals realise that if we do reform the tax system they will be in opposition for a very long time. In l950 and l95l the formula by which money was paid into the account was changed. It was based on payroll tax with an amount paid from Consolidated Revenue which rose proportionately to the increase in payroll tax. That year the amounts were $l0lm from general revenue and $26m from payroll tax. The formula was that as payroll tax increased so too did the amount paid in from Consolidated Revenue. In l952 that scheme was changed to what we have today, so that a sum equal to expenditure was paid into the account from Consolidated Revenue. The Government did not get rid of the Fund; what it did essentially was to make sure that the money that was paid out of the account in any year was matched by money paid into the account from Consolidated Revenue. It is this problem which we are addressing today. We are getting rid of the National Welfare Fund so that payments can be made straight from Consolidated Revenue and not through the Fund. While I am on this subject, I address a question to the Minister who will be wrapping up this debate. I refer to a statement recorded on page 638 of Hansard of l952. Sir Arthur Fadden, the Treasurer of the day, in his second reading speech had this to say, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment of section 5 of the National Welfare Fund Act embodied in the bill will ensure for the fund an annual appropriation from Consolidated Revenue equal to expenditure from the fund; it will preserve the existing balance of #l85,000,000 in the fund and will permit the balance to grow each year by the amount of the income from its investment, which it is estimated will be #l,800,000 . . .

I work that out to be roughly one per cent a year. Whatever became of the #185m which the Fund had accrued until 1952? The National Welfare Fund Repeal Bill 1985 is no more than a tidying up of messy bookkeeping procedures, because all benefits come from Consolidated Revenue.

I have appreciated the opportunity to participate in the debate. It gave me the opportunity to read the history of and debate on this Bill, which was a significant advancement for people at the lower end of the socio-economic structure. This happened in spite of the many demands of the war effort and the ever present, and still continuing, obstruction of conservative forces, which are at this moment waiting in a destructive way to sabotage this Labor Government as it sets itself the difficult task of reforming a tax system that penalises those very same people. We do not run away from the fact that it is a difficult task, but we can draw some strength from the Curtin Government in 1943 which confronted the problem and won some justice for the people of the day despite the many demands on that Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take part in this debate. The winding up of the National Welfare Fund, which is the purpose of the National Welfare Fund Repeal Bill, is an opportune occasion to look at the history of that Fund and to identify some of the opportunities that have been missed to establish for Australians a viable retirement income policy. The National Welfare Fund was set up in 1945 to hold income from a special tax levy to pay for social services expenditure. For a period of five years taxpayers paid tax and a levy in accordance with an Act of Parliament which many taxpayers still remember. It was entitled the Income Tax and Social Services Contribution Act. In 1950, however, after only five years the levy was merged into general tax rates and lost its special significance and function of financing age and other pensions. As I shall point out a little later, I think it is a great pity that the levy was so merged and that there was no attempt to hypothecate out of the general income tax a rate in the dollar sufficient to finance and pay for the ongoing year by year commitment to social security.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1952 the legislation provided that an amount equal to the amount paid out of the Fund be paid into it from general revenue. With this change, the Fund's assets ceased to accumulate. While there was a levy, if the levy exceeded the pension payout, the assets of the Fund accumulated. Once the levy ceased there was no accounting mechanism which tied expenditure on pensions to income tax collections. The funds that had accumulated up to the time when there ceased to be a levy were left in the Fund. They were invested in internal Treasury bills. Those bills bore interest so the Fund tended to increase over the years. While the Fund was still used for the purpose of financing pensions, it was replenished to the full extent of annual pension costs by transfers from general revenue. However, the amount in the Fund accumulated as a consequence of interest received from the investment of the accumulated balance of the Fund. In 1976 it was decided that the so-called 'historical balance' would be paid into Consolidated Revenue. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) asked where the money had gone. As I pointed out, it was invested in internal Treasury bills. The bills were redeemed and the money, simply by book entry, was absorbed into Consolidated Revenue. The amount at that time was some $470m.

The National Welfare Fund Repeal Bill, which is now before the House, simply aims at removing an accounting requirement-an empty shell. It is a Fund with no money in it, except that which it receives each year, an amount equal to that which was paid out each year. That is the purpose of the Bill. I think it is a pity that the levy or hypothecation concept has not been used over a long period to identify that proportion of our income tax used to meet the cost of aged pensions. If the amount equal to the commitment for age pensions had been hypothecated out of income tax, we as a society would have some better comprehension of the cost of providing senior citizens with an adequate income.

Since the Hawke Government came to office, the continued evolution of Australia's age pension scheme into a universal flat rate non-contributory age pension scheme has received a number of setbacks. The anomaly-ridden assets test has been imposed. The Labor Party, by imposing the assets test and by abolishing means test free pensions for those over 70, has blocked the emergence of what would have been a national superannuation scheme. If such a scheme had been allowed to develop to the point where universal flat rate pensions were payable to all at the age of 65 or at pensionable age, it would have provided maximum encouragement and reward for self provision at levels of income above the flat rate pension. There is overwhelming public support for the introduction of a universal superannuation scheme which not only provides everyone with a guaranteed adequate income but also rewards those who choose to save for retirement by postponing expenditure during their income-earning years. In contrast to the government run earnings related pension schemes which have been proposed from time to time, a universal flat rate pension scheme would encourage the natural growth of existing occupational superannuation schemes rather than have an adverse effect on their development.

Such a flat rate universal social security pension would provide every Australian with security as to his or her minimum income entitlement on reaching retirement age. As a result, a climate would be created in which everyone who wished to do so could, by forgoing current expenditure, divert current earnings into the accumulation of either wealth or entitlement to future pension payments. The Government regulation and control of occupational superannuation schemes and other forms of provision for retirement should be kept to a minimum. It is, however, desirable in my view that, like life insurance companies, superannuation funds should be required to meet reasonable prudential standards.

Tax incentives are often used to encourage provision for retirement through superannuation funds. Where this is done, it is highly desirable that no such tax concessions, whatever their form, be made available unless the funds satisfy certain reasonable conditions. The availability of these tax concessions should be conditional on superannuation schemes containing provisions relating to vesting, preservation and portability. Only by requiring preservation of benefits until retirement, other than in exceptional circumstances, only by encouraging portability and only by requiring fair and reasonable rules relating to the vesting of employer contributions can the Government be assured that by forgoing revenue the members of superannuation funds will be better off and more appropriately provided for in retirement than otherwise would be the case.

It is not in the Government's interest only that these standards be required of superannuation funds; in the ultimate it is in the interest of taxpayers that those who benefit from the concessions provide for their retirement and not for other needs. The purpose of that forgoing of revenue is achieved by those who save in superannuation schemes having the funds available when they reach retiring age, not when those funds have been dissipated well before retirement. Except to the extent that the aged survive by running down their assets, incomes for the aged can be provided only by transferring current purchasing power from the employed work force.

This is true whether the transfer occurs through the use of taxes collected largely from the employed work force or through money received by the aged as part of the profit share they derive from their invested savings. Instead of concerning themselves with the well being of all who have reached retiring age, over the last 40 years governments have too often focused their attention only on what in the jargon is described as public sector social expenditure on the aged. If government attention had been directed not only to public sector but also to private sector spending at this time, means test-free pensions would not have been abandoned, the assets test would not have been reintroduced and we would have been continuing the movement towards the introduction of universal means test-free pensions for our senior citizens.

In many countries the viability of current systems of social security is being questioned. The growth of outlays seems to be outstripping the community's capacity or willingness to pay through taxation. In Australia, social security outlays during the decade of the 1970s grew at an annual rate in real terms of l0.5 per cent per annum. This was twice as fast as the annual growth rate in real terms of the gross domestic product. When we look for the causes of this we find three: The first was the demographic change which occurred over this period, the second was the result of policy decisions to improve benefits and extend eligibility and the third was the impact of adverse economic conditions.

Australia's population is slowly aging. More people are living longer, but probably of greater impact is the decline in the rate of population growth due to the fall in the birth-rate and the introduction of restrictive immigration policies. In l980, about ll.7 per cent of the population was of pensionable age. This percentage is expected to increase to about l3.7 per cent in the year 2000. The ratio of the aged to the working age population will increase from l8.5 per cent to 2l.7 per cent at the end of this century. On the other hand, the ratio of dependent children to the working population is expected to decline. Because of this and the expected continuing rise in work force participation rates, the standard of living of the working population will not need to be cut back in direct proportion to the increase in age dependency. However, it is important to note that the public sector-private sector mix of social expenditure on the aged is not the same as the mix of that expenditure on children.

Unless the objectives of government policies are to create a social and economic climate which results in a greater degree of private provision for retirement, the aging of the population will result in an increase in public sector and a decline in private sector social expenditure in the support of those in the community who are dependants. Such a change in the mix of private and public sector social expenditure implies increasing tax burdens and a considerable increase in average tax rates for the years ahead. The alternative is for government to encourage a greater degree of private provision for retirement. A greater reliance on the private sector for income security would reduce the financing problem faced by the public sector. It would also give private individuals when they reach retirement the satisfaction that they have provided for themselves a degree of self-reliance, a feeling that they are not dependent upon the taxpayer. Even if this were to be achieved, however, it is important to recognise that, from a macroeconomic point of view, social expenditure on children and social expenditure on the aged is a burden in respect of all children and in respect of all aged, and is a burden on the economy, whether the expenditure is public expenditure or private expenditure. The critical thing for the quality of our provision for the dependent sectors in the community is the mix between public sector and private sector expenditure.

It is my view that we should be spending much more time putting in much more effort in devising ways and means whereby people can themselves provide for their children and can themselves provide for their retirement. This can only be achieved by having a taxation system which is fair to those who are looking after dependants-a system which fully and adequately recompenses them for carrying the burden of looking after people who would otherwise be dependent upon the taxpayer, thereby increasing public sector expenditure.

In Australia, the use of public revenue to finance social security is an important element of our income maintenance system. The flat rate benefits provided by the present Australian system do not necessary imply a low level of earnings replacement. On the contrary, for many low income earners the replacement rates are quite high. The Australian system has the advantage of catering better for the needs of persons who have never been attached to the work force in any way than many of the much vaunted schemes from overseas that provide benefits only to those who have contributed, whether as tax or levy payers or contributors in other ways. The imposition of the social security levy, which was abolished some years ago and which was the mechanism whereby the social welfare fund was replenished with its funds in the first five years of its operation, did not work because the amount of the levy was not adjusted to raise the amount needed to meet the Government's annual pension commitment. Like the Medicare levy, it was nothing more than an additional form of taxation bearing no relationship to the costs incurred on Medicare or on pensions for the aged. It would have been a good idea if the proportion of income tax required to finance the social welfare fund had been identified year by year for the last 40 years.

Full hypothecation of the cost of providing pensions to the aged would have given the taxpaying public a greater understanding of the extent of the resource transfers necessary to provide for the aged. If during l984-85 that proportion of income tax needed to fund all pensions payable to persons of pensionable age had been hypothecated in this way by way of a flat rate levy, it would have represented 6.5c out of every dollar in respect of which a taxpayer now pays tax. If the rate of hypothecation out of the taxes paid were to be the same as the progression as is contained in the current rate scale, those who are paying 25c in the dollar would have been paying 5.2c of their tax of 25c in the dollar by way of social security levy for the aged and those paying 60c in the dollar would have been paying l2.4c out of the 60 cents in the dollar by way of their contribution towards providing incomes for the aged.

If there were a universal means test-free eligibility for the aged pension, the flat rate levy required would be 7.2 per cent and, if such a levy was to be on the progressive scale as set out in the current tax schedules, it would be 5.8 per cent for the 25c in the dollar taxpayer and l3.9 per cent for the 60c in the dollar taxpayer.

Recently the social welfare policy secretariat commissioned a most interesting study. It revealed that, if single persons of pensionable age were to be paid pensions or to have available to them income equal to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and if married couples were to have incomes equal to 42 per cent of average weekly earnings, the cost of these income transfers would have amounted to an estimated 6.46 per cent of expected total employed earnings. The burden of these transfers is expected to rise to 7.4 per cent of total employed earnings by the year 2000. If the retiring age were in fact to become 60 years for men and women, and the income entitlement of single retirees were to rise to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings and that of married retirees were to rise to 50 per cent of average weekly earnings, the proportion of expected total employed persons' earnings required to finance these transfers would be nearly l0 per cent.

In conclusion, I make a plea to this House and to the Government to examine the total question of income transfers to the aged. If the Government wants to achieve a reduction in the public sector burden of providing incomes for the aged it must pay much more attention to giving encouragement and reward to those who seek to provide for retirement for themselves. The time has come when we should more constantly measure the total cost to the working population of those who are dependent in our society and debate the question of how we can most efficiently provide that income.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members will be aware, the National Welfare Fund was established as a trust fund in l943. At that time it was proposed that a levy taken from people's taxable income be paid into that Fund out of which would be paid various social security benefits. I guess that in l943 there were people in the Parliament, as there are in the Opposition now, who believed that we should have a funded welfare system. Fortunately for the Australian people it took the national Parliament only a short period-that is, until about l952-to realise that it was not really possible to have a funded welfare system.
—They didn't try.

—Later on attempts were made under the Fraser Government and other conservative governments to reintroduce some type of levy funded welfare system. A member of the Opposition interjected a moment ago that the governments never tried to have a funded welfare service. I suppose that it is fair enough for someone who is quite wealthy, as are most members of parliament compared with people who are in receipt of social security benefits, to say that governments never try. However, governments throughout the rest of the Western world have not succeeded in this respect. That great proponent of monetarist policies in theory but not in fact, Ronald Reagan, at one stage was going to let the United States social security service go broke because it was not funded on a proper actuarial basis. He talked a lot but did nothing. Governments of both the East and West have realised that a measure of a government's capacity to assist its people and a measure of a government's civilisation are its ability to take care of those in society who are least able to care for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The propositions put forward by members of the Opposition about a funded welfare system go hand in hand with a system of tax deductibility for the contributions that people of thrift-and we hear a lot of talk about people of thrift-put aside for themselves. It is very easy for people on good incomes to put aside money for their future retirement. However, it is very difficult for people on very low wages or, indeed, as we are seeing in Australia and other parts of the Western world at present, people on no wages, to put aside anything. These people would have to pay more under a funded system. People on good incomes can afford to contribute to such a system because they receive tax deductibility in respect of their superannuation payments. I must say that as a member of Parliament-and no doubt, you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would agree with me-the largest single tax deduction that I have is my superannuation payments. The largest single tax deduction that I had when I was a public servant was my superannuation payments.

Some people are fortunate enough to be able to invest up to $l,200 a year in superannuation schemes which they can claim as a tax deduction. This is a pretty good investment for people who are being taxed at a high marginal income tax rate of 60c in the dollar because every year they get back $720 of the $l,200 that they have put away for their retirement. But where does the $720 come from? It does not come from all of their colleagues who are doing all right out of life because they are able to contribute $l,200 in superannuation payments. The money comes from the low income earners and people who cannot afford to put aside $l,200 per annum, or $24 a week, to fund their superannuation benefits which they will receive at some later date. I guess that all of us would like to feel that the whole of society was wealthy enough to be able to put aside $24 a week for retirement purposes and to receive a 60 per cent tax deduction. Unfortunately, many members tend to lose touch with reality when they come into this place. A vast number of people out there in our society do not have anywhere near that type of disposable income each week, each year, for the rest of their lives. So what the proposition put forward by the Opposition for a funded welfare service tied in with tax deductibility does is provide a very substantial tax benefit to those people on high salaries. The people who pay for that tax benefit are those on low and medium salaries. The poor unfortunates who are not receiving any income at all, other than welfare payments, do not even get into the race.

Members of the Opposition would take us back to l943 and say: 'Well, we need to have a funded system'. It does not matter to them that even a Liberal government in l952 decided that a funded system would not work. Like King Canute, they really think that they can turn back the tide. We hear a lot of bleating from members of the Opposition who, in attempting to frighten governments into adopting a funded system, say: 'Well, of course, if you do not do something about this, the aging of the population is going to bury you all in the high cost of welfare payments'. But they are the same people who say that the family allowance is sacrosanct, that we have to keep paying a non-means tested family allowance to middle class and wealthy women. They do not want to look at the equity in that case but they are trying to make the aged contribute to a funded welfare system.

There is no sense, justice or consistency in the argument put forward by most members of the Opposition in support of funded welfare services. I must say that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), has done a lot of work over a long period to convince his colleagues that they should advocate such a system. Fortunately for those who are not so well off in Australia, he has not been able to convince many of them. I hope that he will not be able to do so for some time to come.

The Opposition has always taken the view that somehow or other-and I am sure that the honourable member's colleague who is seeking to interject will have something to say about this in a few moments when he speaks in this debate-there is something good to be said about people contributing to their retirement. I believe that people contribute substantially to their own retirement through the taxation system. I think that the tax system, as a mechanism for attempting to bring about some levelling up in society, is a far better way of funding welfare services than levies. I must say that I and some of my colleagues thought that one of the more successful propositions put forward by honourable members opposite when they were previously in opposition was to strike down the Medibank levy. As a result, that scheme had to be funded out of Consolidated Revenue. I had hoped that they might have done the same thing again, but unfortunately they did not. So there are inconsistencies in the point of view taken by the Opposition.

There are misapprehensions, too, in the general population about what should be done with the welfare system. Many of those misapprehensions go back to the concept behind the National Welfare Fund Act l943, because people who are now aged and who have been contributing for many years to what they thought was that fund are of the view that everyone is entitled to a pension because everyone has paid taxes. It is very important that the Government is now repealing that legislation. It has not really been in effect since l952. No one has contributed since 1952 to any fund for pensions through the government system, but there is still the view, reinforced by some of the changes to the social security system that the Opposition made when in government, that people are paying into some levy fund and that they are entitled, by virtue of that, to a pension.

We have this universalist approach in the community. The Opposition contributed to that when in government, as did some of my colleagues when in government in the past, by doing away with the income test on the pension so that some people, as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) told the Parliament a couple of days ago, had assets in excess of $lm and managed to collect a social security pension. The guidelines for getting a pension provide that one should not have much income. However, people got around that by converting income into capital goods and then using them up as it suited them. Having no assets test on the pension contributed to this concept that it was the right of everyone to have a pension. I do not think it is the right of people, except for financial reasons-that they do not have the means to support themselves-to get a pension.

There should be equity in the social security system, which should provide support for those in need and not for those who rearrange their situation so that the system is helping them-not because they are needy, but because they are greedy. The present Government has attempted to redress some of the more overt rorts involved in that system by bringing in the assets test and by providing for taxes on lump sum superannuation payments. Members of the Opposition have suggested that the Government should encourage more private superannuation schemes, but in the past the response of the employers and private superannuation firms to a privately funded superannuation scheme was to come up with lump sum systems. When that was coupled with the capital goods provisions of the social security system, people could retire on a lump sum of $l00,000 or $200,000 and still arrange their affairs so that they got the pension, when they should have been investing that money and getting a weekly income so that taxpayers did not have to subsidise them.

As one of the previous Opposition speakers has said, we even had a means test-free pension for people over 70. We had the ludicrous situation of a former Prime Minister, a recognised millionaire, receiving the age pension. That idea comes from a party which believes that we ought to put equity into the system. The Opposition's idea of equity and the idea that ordinary Australians have of equity are quite different. The sort of system in which people contribute to funded schemes leaves itself open to the worst types of abuse.

The private superannuation system has never voluntarily addressed itself to paying weekly pensions to people in the schemes. It has always wanted to pay lump sums because that suits employers and that suits it. Now that the Government has placed a tax on lump sum payments, some superannuation organisations are looking to fund annuities. They are saying to the Government: 'You have to help us more. You have to allow us to have indexed bonds so that we can fund this'. The response by the private superannuation industry, which members of the Opposition suggest can really help us fund the responsibility for the aged, has been to say: 'The Government has to give us another perk'. It is not good enough that the Government gives a tax deduction of up to $1,200 a year for those in private superannuation funds, in fact in all superannuation funds; the industry now wants indexed bonds.

If the Government ever decided to allow private entrepreneurs and private insurance companies to run the Government's social security system, constant demands would be made on the Government to change the system, because these companies would say: 'We cannot go on any longer'. In my opinion, it is up to governments to fund and control the social security system. If governments ever step out and leave it to the market place, those who are less able to fend for themselves will be thrown on the scrap-heap once again. I do not know where we would find a private superannuation group that would fund the supporting parent's benefit or a private superannuation group or, indeed, a workers' compensation insurer that would fund sickness benefits.

Too frequently, constituents have said to me that the doctor, or someone else in the workers' compensation field, has told them that they ought to get on to the invalid pension after they have received a workers' compensation payment. The lawyers never tell them that the workers' compensation payment is supposed to provide income for the rest of their lives. They use up a fair amount of it and find themselves a burden on the public purse. If the private insurers who run not only workers' compensation but also superannuation schemes were so socially conscious, one would have thought that they would have been saying to people on workers' compensation payments: 'Really, this payment is to help you out for the rest of your life. It is not to pay for your house, to buy a new car or to go on an overseas trip'.

We have seen the failure of the private sector to address itself responsibly to being able to fund the welfare service in Australia. The moves that the present Government has made to put more equity into the system are to be commended. I find it repugnant that the Minister for Social Security had to tell us in the House last week that, through the assets test, the Government had discovered that l2 millionaires were receiving the pension. Some of the Opposition members then interjected: 'Only l2?' I think that one millionaire receiving a pension is a terrible reflection on the type of social security system that the Opposition would like Australia to have. The government is there to provide a safety net and to help those in need.

This Government's move to repeal the National Welfare Fund Act l943 says once and for all that governments accept that, through Consolidated Revenue, they have an obligation to fund the country's welfare system. To my mind and, I am sure, to the minds of other members, to those in society who believe that, somehow, they are entitled to a pension because they have paid their taxes this will make the point that that is wrong and that the Government will put the social security system on a firm footing by funding those in need rather than those whose activity has been motivated by greed.

The way in which private insurers, in both the workers compensation area and the superannuation area, funded their arrangements in the past pandered to those who were greedy. The tax system still provides a substantial benefit to those people who are in expensive private superannuation schemes. I am glad to see that we have finally got away from the ridiculous position which existed whereby some people in the country still held on to the view that somehow or other we had to have a market forces welfare policy in Australia.

The war effort, particularly under the Labor governments, saw this reduced significantly. However, the Curtin Government saw that there was a need to provide income security for the population of Australia. To quote Chifley:

SPEECH.PARA: One of our aims is the securing for all improved labour standards, economic advancement and social security.
I quote from volume l73, page 548, of Hansard. He went on to say:

Measures directed to these ends must aim at ensuring a high level of employment, which is fundamental to economic advancement and social security. Further measures are necessary to ensure minimum social standards throughout the community.

In other words, the Chifley Government's plan for economic advancement lay between two primary foundations: Firstly, ensuring that the level of employment was high; and, secondly, ensuring that those who could not earn income should not have to suffer the consequences of poverty. So even amongst the turmoil and hardship of the war, Australia, with a wartime Labor Government, clearly had turned its priority to the aged, the sick, the widowed and the other underprivileged sections of the community. The elimination of poverty and a high level of employment were fundamental to the advancement of the country. This breadth of vision is the political inheritance of this reforming Hawke Labor Government. This vision and difference in approach are what distinguishes Labor governments from those of the Liberal and National parties. It is relevant today, just as it was relevant during the Second World War. It is appropriate to recall the proud reforming record of the Curtin and Chifley governments in the field of social security, which was impressive. It made provision for widows' pensions in l942, maternity benefits for Aboriginal mothers in l942, reciprocity with New Zealand in old age and invalid pensions in l943, unemployment and sickness benefits in l944, pharmaceutical benefits in l944, hospital benefits in l945, tuberculosis benefits in l945, and the Commonwealth Employment Service.

In l943 the National Welfare Fund Bill became an Act of Parliament. The moneys were to be transferred to the Fund from Consolidated Revenue to the tune of $30m, or 25 per cent of personal income tax, whichever was the lesser amount. In l946 a specific and separate levy on incomes was operated to finance the Fund. This was due to increasing outlays on social services. The Government felt that a new financial approach was needed. The Government proposed to charge all health and social services expenditure to the one fund-the National Welfare Fund. The Fund was generally and popularly described as being a non-contributory fund. That is true. Having listened to my learned colleague the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), I want to make a few explanations. A truly contributory fund is essentially one from which people receive what they put in. It is true to say that it was not a contributory fund. The beneficiaries were not the contributors. Rather they are the current pensioners and social welfare recipients. Indeed, tax returns showed the amount of income tax paid and a separate amount for the social security levy. Honourable members may understand that this system was liked by many as it clearly established the contributions being made towards a future entitlement for a pension although, as I have said, it was actually paying for the current pensioners.

Financing the Fund passed to payroll taxes an amount equal to updated l950-5l levy contributions. Income tax returns no longer showed the two separate amounts. In l952 the Fund was financed from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Payments into the Fund equalled appropriations from the Fund. The Fund became an accounting mechanism only. In l976 the accumulated balance was paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The mechanics of the Act no longer serve any useful purpose. Its repeal is timely. This Hawke Labor Government is determined--

Let us look at the levels of real economic growth which, in my opinion, is the ultimate test of any government's economic performance. Under the coalition we had growth in gross domestic product of a massive one half of one per cent in the year to September l982. Under the Hawke Government we had real growth of 4.3 per cent in the year to September l984. Under Treasurer Howard home approvals fell to a low of 8,600 in October l982. Under Treasurer Keating home approvals had risen to l3,500 in February l985. Under the Liberals new motor vehicle registrations fell to only 32,000 in February l983. Under Labor this had risen from 32,000 to 47,500 in February l985. This Government deserves full credit for the current economic recovery, and in particular the Treasurer is to be congratulated on the rapid turn-round in the national economy.

I was very encouraged by the Treasurer's reply to my question without notice in this chamber last Thursday. The Treasurer advised the House that the December national accounts confirmed the underlying strength of the recovery. Gross domestic product rose by a further l.2 per cent in the December quarter; gross non-farm product rose by 5.l per cent over the year to December l984. Under the Liberals in 1982 the figure was 0.9 of one per cent. Under Labor in l983 we raised the figure to 2.6 per cent. The Treasurer's great success this year is that he has raised that figure again by 5.l per cent, a great achievement. Even the honourable member for Bennelong welcomed the economic growth disclosed by last Thursday's figures. Last Thursday, the Sydney Morning Herald quoted the Deputy Leader of the Opposition as conceding: 'This is good economic news for Australia'. This is a welcome change from the usual doom and gloom predictions we have come to expect from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and most Opposition members. Sometimes I think the Opposition would rejoice if the recovery faltered, but I am sure that the vast majority of Australians will join with me in congratulating the Treasurer on his success to date.

Let us compare the standing of Labor's Treasurer with the alternative offered by the Liberals. Frankly, I am amazed that the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) continues to allow the honourable member for Bennelong to be shadow Treasurer. Not only was his performance as Treasurer in the Fraser years woeful, but he sought to deceive the Australian people on the state of the nation's finances during the l983 election campaign. Members will recall how, as Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong was advised by John Stone, his loyal departmental secretary, only five days before the election that the l983-84 deficit would be $9 billion. The honourable member for Bennelong conspired with Malcolm Fraser to have this information kept secret from the Australian people. They conspired to have this information kept secret because it proved beyond all doubt that under the Liberals the economy was out of control. The honourable member for Bennelong's recent statements calling on the Hawke Government to reduce expenditure and rein in the deficit should be judged in this light. He was the Treasurer who presided over the greatest blowout in the deficit in Australia's economic history.

Recent Press reports suggest that perhaps the honourable member for Bennelong may be replaced as Deputy Leader of the Opposition by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). Let us look at the income policy of the honourable member for Tangney, as he is the Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations. His great brainwave is that if the Liberals were returned to government he would abandon centralised wage fixing and would allow market forces to fix wage rates through collective bargaining. This great breakthrough in policy formulation is a great leap back to l982 when the now Leader of the Opposition in exile, Malcolm Fraser, sought to solve the wages explosion by allowing collective bargaining. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) in the House, as I am about to quote from a newspaper report of a top secret speech delivered by Malcolm Fraser at a testimonial to the former member for Bass. I quote from a report in the Australian which said that Mr Fraser 'admitted to mistakes during his prime ministership, including indirect ''responsibility'' for the l982 wages explosion which seriously exacerbated the recession'. What caused the wages explosion? It was caused by the simple fact that the Liberals did not have an incomes policy.

The Liberals went to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and argued that centralised wage fixing be abandoned. Unfortunately, the Arbitration Commission accepted their arguments and centralised wage fixing was abandoned. As a result we had one of the greatest increases in wages and one of the greatest increases in the rate of inflation, for the simple reason that the Liberals wanted to abandon centralised wage fixing. The great brainwave of the honourable member for Tangney, the new spokesman on employment and industrial relations, is to go back to the failed and discredited policies of the Fraser years.

I now turn to the level of funding for roads. I am well qualified to speak on this matter because, in my opinion, the roads on the Central Coast of New South Wales are the worst in any outer metropolitan area in Australia. The quality of the roads on the Central Coast is bad for three reasons: Firstly, we have had a rapid increase in population on the Central Coast of New South Wales in the last l0 years. At the moment we are averaging an increase of over 8 per cent each year. The second reason is that the Fraser Government cut back funding for roadworks during its term of office. The third reason is the Askin Liberal Government's failure to allocate funds to the Central Coast during the Askin Government's years in office.

I will just say a few words about the performance of the Askin Government on roads and other matters. It should not be forgotten that two members of this House here today were in fact Ministers of the Askin Liberal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who were they? Name them.

—I will leave that to the honourable member's imagination. It also should not be forgotten that the current leader of the National Party of Australia in the New South Wales Parliament, the Hon. Leon Punch, was also the Deputy Premier during the Askin days. Before the Askin Government came to power the Renshaw Labor Government commenced the construction of the F3 freeway from Berowra to Calga. During the ll years of the Askin Government construction of that freeway did not proceed one inch. There were no extensions to the freeway during the entire period of the Askin Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is so long since the Liberals have had an elected representative from the Central Coast of New South Wales that I sometimes doubt whether they know where the Central Coast is. Since 1976 the Liberal Party has not succeeded in having a representative from the Central Coast elected to the State Parliament or the Federal Parliament. I was not surprised that the Liberal Party had to go to great lengths to obtain a candidate to stand against me in the division of Dobell. It went all the way to the St George district of Sydney to obtain a candidate. Apparently, none of the members of the Liberal Party in the electorate of Dobell wished to run as a candidate. The Liberal candidate paid the people of Dobell the compliment of moving into the electorate one day before the rolls were ruled off.

I now compare the performance of the Askin Liberal Government with that of the Wran Labor Government. The Wran Labor Government, in partnership with the Australian Government, has allocated funds to allow the following projects to be completed or to be near completion today: The first project is the upgrading of the Pacific Highway, for which $lm was allocated for a dual carriageway from the F3 motorway to Doyalson. Over $lm was allocated for a second carriageway from Elizabeth Bay Road to Kanangra Drive, Lake Munmorah. There was also the construction of a pedestrian bridge at Lake Munmorah Public School to allow the school children to cross the Pacific Highway. There was also the F3 freeway which was extended over nine kilometres from Wyong River to Wallarah Creek at a cost of almost $7m. Over l6 kilometres of freeway work was commenced, at a total cost of over $27m, which will provide a dual carriageway all the way from Wallarah Creek to Dora Creek, in the electorate of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown).

In addition there was work on the F3 freeway from Calga to Somersby, which is costing over $l0m and which also includes work on the famous Moonie Moonie Bridge which I understand will be nearing completion next year. There was the construction of a new bridge over Tuggerah Lakes, for which the Federal Government provided $l.6m. There is also the Rutile Road from Budgewoi to Elizabeth Bay, which was also granted over half a million dollars by the Federal Government.

Just over two weeks ago my colleague the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) announced a new deal for roadworks funding throughout Australia. In my maiden speech I predicted that Peter Morris would be remembered as Australia's greatest post-war Minister for Transport. I stand by that prediction. The Minister's announced program demonstrates the farsighted approach that he has brought to his portfolio. For the first time, all federal funding to the States and local government for road works will be provided from a guaranteed and indexed share of fuel excise. I pay a compliment to the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) who introduced a similar program for the Australian bicentennial road development program. I am sure that members of the National Party will join with the Government in extending that policy to all funding for road works. This will provide a legislative guarantee that federal funding will be maintained in real terms for five years at the l985-86 level. This will allow the States and local government to plan road works with confidence as they will know how much funding will be available. Contractors will be able to make informed decisions on whether additional or improved plant and machinery should be purchased.

I have heard that some State roads Ministers have criticised the Minister's announced program. I was concerned to read in the Gosford Star last week that statements had been made by the New South Wales Minister for Roads and that these statements led the Mayor of Gosford, Alderman Peter Coleman, to say that he was very worried that major roadworks in Gosford were in jeopardy. I will spend a few minutes examining the program of the Federal Minister for Transport, to see whether these worries are justified. First of all, let us look at the total amount of funds which are to be allocated to road funding. This year the Minister is proposing to allocate $l,245m for roadworks. That compares with only $685m in l98l-82, the last full year of the Fraser Government. That shows that in the period that Labor has been in office we have raised spending on roads by 82 per cent, which is a 36 per cent increase in real terms. That is something for which the Minister deserves full credit.

This year there will be a total of $392m in Federal funding to New South Wales for roadworks. That compares with only $2l4m in l98l-82. Again that is an increase of over 83 per cent. Funding on the national roads program for New South Wales has increased by over 90 per cent from l98l-82 to 1985-86. Funds provided for local roads have increased by almost 60 per cent from 1981-82 to 1985-86. The New South Wales Minister appeared to criticise the Federal Minister most over the funding for arterial roads, so let us look at the grants for arterial roads. For l985-86 the Government is proposing to spend $l2lm. In l98l-82-the last full year of the Fraser Government-$46m, less than half that, was allocated. Again that is an increase of over 88 per cent.

Since l98l-82 the New South Wales Government has increased its spending on roads from $378m to $548m in l984-85. New South Wales increased its spending by 45 per cent. Federal funding to New South Wales has increased from $2l4m to $392m, an increase of 83 per cent. At the federal level the funding for roadworks to New South Wales has increased by 83 per cent. New South Wales has raised its own spending on roads by only 43 per cent. Therefore, the question has to be asked: Is it time that the New South Wales Government lifted its share of spending on roads? The Federal Government has done more than its fair share. It has raised its spending by over 83 per cent.

In the few minutes that are left to me I would like to touch on two matters. The Liberal Party in the electorate of Dobell, as do members of the Liberal Party in this House, sought to make a great deal of political capital out of the assets test. The Liberal candidate for Dobell sought to convince the pensioners in the electorate that all the information they put on their assets test form would go into a computer and that criminal elements would have access to it. This is complete rubbish. In fact, only 0.9 of one per cent of pensioners in the electorate of Dobell, which with 16,000 has the largest number of pensioners of any electorate in New South Wales, have had their pensions reduced or cut out. So much for the scare tactics of the Liberal Party.
Finally, I wish to touch on the issue of local government funding. At the moment local government is allocated 2 per cent of income tax receipts.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do with it-wipe it out?

—In case the honourable member is not aware of what happens, let me tell him what the problem is in respect of allocating 2 per cent of income tax receipts. When the Government of which the honourable member was a supporter ran the economy we had a recession which meant that local government's share of funding was cut back by a very large amount. Under good Labor economic management we have had a massive increase in income tax receipts. As a result, local government is expecting a big increase this year. I am sure that honourable members will join with me in hoping that the amount of money which is granted to local government will be maintained in real terms. I think it is time that we changed the way in which local government is funded. Instead of giving local government a percentage of personal income tax we should be giving it a set percentage of total tax receipts and so avoid the wild fluctuations that occur. Whenever honourable members opposite are in government the economy falls to pieces and there is a decline in income tax receipts. We want to make sure that there is not a fall-off in local government funding 20 years from now when, perhaps, honourable members opposite are re-elected to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 3) l984-85 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) l984-85 have been introduced for the purpose of appropriating additional expenditure. The Attorney-General's Department needs another $7m. I imagine that that has something to do with legal aid and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Defence needs another $250m. The increased expenditure in this area is worth while because defence is one of the few areas in respect of which an increased allocation is justified. Under this Government, our defence forces are being run down. The Government is not interested in defence. It has knocked us out of ANZUS. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the socialist Prime Minister of New Zealand do not seem to be terribly interested in defence in this part of the world. The ANZUS Treaty is in ruins. TALK.START.PARA: —They took it off him.

—Yes, they took it off him because he was not able to give any direction in that area. As I said, the tax summit is a total charade. We still do not know who is going to be invited to the summit. I hope that I, as someone representing 80,000 electors in the great electorate of Maranoa, get an invitation to the summit. I represent 80,000 people who are involved in producing some of the wealth of this nation. These people are not dependent on enormous amounts of handout money, as are people in areas such as the capital cities. The farm industries, the great mining industries, the oil industry and so on of this country more than pay their way. The oil producing area of Jackson and the mining area of Blackwater and others which produce vast amounts of coal are enormous revenue earners in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister seems to think he should have a summit on taxation. Every day he comes up with a new summit for something or other. Of course, we know that he fell off the top of a summit some months ago because he has never been the same since he backed down from the MX missile negotiations. That was a total farce. Even I thought that he had a bit of gumption. However, of course, from that day on he has been slowly backing himself out of office and he will not last at the next election.

The amount of tax revenue for Queensland has been cut back by $250m. In fact, the amount of tax revenue for all other States has been cut back. The Hawke Government says that it will cut back expenditure. It will force the States to increase their taxes so that the Commonwealth will not have to take the responsibility and increase its taxes. The amount of revenue that every State is to get from the Commonwealth funding arrangements will be cut back enormously. Of course, the amount to be allocated to Queensland is to be cut back by $250m. Queensland has been very much in the forefront of events in the last few weeks largely because of the power strike that has taken place in that part of the world. The Electrical Trades Union people decided some months ago to go on strike. Of course, we have all been out of power. I personally have suffered from lack of power on my own property. We ran out of water for stock because of that dispute. We had to go to bed with a candle-and that was to give us light. Of course, we did not have power for irrigation and all sorts of other farm endeavours. All the small industries throughout Maranoa and the rest of Queensland were completely out of power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrible.

—It is a shocking state of affairs. The Premier of Queensland is the only Premier who is prepared to stand up to the unions. The Federal Government is not prepared to back the Premier of Queensland against the unions. The Government has back-shuffled away--
—Robin Gray did something.

—Robin Gray is the only one who would be prepared to stand up with Joh. But at long last we have a Premier who is prepared to stand up to the unions. The Prime Minister wants to negotiate with Joh. However, the Premier of Queensland is not prepared to negotiate. We finished and settled this strike a month ago. The power came back on a month ago. The power has not been turned off since and it will continue that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the sitting was suspended, I was explaining how I felt that it was unnecessary for the Labor Government to have a tax summit as today we heard the announcement that it is going to increase the price of fuel--

—Yes, by 3.9c a litre. This will bring in another $642m in revenue. I put it to the Government that at this rate it will be unnecessary for it to have a summit if the tax take from fuel alone is to continue to increase. We have seen the dollar drop out of sight; it has been as low as US61c. Now that the Government is to review the parity pricing policy every two months, judging by the dollar's performance in the previous two months it could drop another US10c to US50c, which would give the Government at least another $600m to $700m in revenue. So it is really not necessary to have a tax summit. Our great white leader, the Prime Minister, told us that he was going to knock down the price of fuel by 3c a litre, but since he has come to office we have seen an increase of between 3c and 15c a litre in the price of petrol. It is terribly difficult for us, particularly the farming and business communities, to continue at this rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter of concern is the Queensland electricity strike. It is important to remember that all workers who were sacked have been offered re-employment under certain conditions. It is also important to remember that they are covered by a no-strike clause. We in Queensland argue that it is absolutely vital that essential services be maintained. Those workers are getting extra pay and better conditions to work in those areas. They are privileged workers because of the amount of pay and the conditions, leave and so on, offered to them to work in those essential service areas, six or seven days a week if they have to, to maintain power. It is most important for us to remember that.

Another matter mentioned in the Bill is extra funds for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Department of Communications has an allocation of an extra $12m. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) is not here, but I ask him to make sure that the satellite receiving dishes in western Queensland receive an ABC program produced in Queensland, including weather forecasts. Presently people in western Queensland are getting a forecast from Sydney. Mr Speaker, if you were sitting at home in your electorate receiving a forecast from Queensland, you would not be very happy about it. On the other hand, many Queenslanders have to watch a New South Wales forecast in a Sydney-produced program. They do not know what is going on. They do not know what their weather is going to be. Cyclones and all sorts of things crop up in inland Queensland and people, particularly in the electorate of Maranoa, want to know what is going on. Under the ABC's present arrangements, they do not have a clue because the present Government is not giving them the programs that they ought to be getting through the ABC and the new National program. There is a lot of good in the new National program. There is also a lot of bad.

The transmission we are getting in outback Queensland is being produced in Sydney, and it is not good enough. All the graft and corruption in New South Wales being beamed into Queensland is more than we can take. It is something that we clean living people are not prepared to accept. I put it to the Minister that this extra money, this $12.201m, ought to be spent on giving the good people of Maranoa at least a program that is produced in Queensland, particularly a weather forecast. Those of us who live in the bush like to see a proper weather map every day, particularly at this time of the year when we have cyclones and so on. No other State would accept this situation. But, of course, Queensland has to take second best. We will not accept it any longer. I am asking the Minister to do something about it. This afternoon the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) told us that he was going to make airports commercial and profitable. I interjected. I was not named in this case--

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that hard to believe!

—I do, too, but I interjected and suggested that, if it is good enough to expect airports to pay their way, it is good enough to expect the buses in Canberra to pay their way. They run at a $50m loss a year. Commonwealth railways run at a loss each year of $50m to $100m. I put it to honourable members that, if it is good enough for those others in country areas to make our airports pay, it is good enough for those who live in city electorates to make sure that this cuts across the board and that not just airports suffer. As you would know, Mr Speaker, aircraft flights in inland Australia are most important for the every day carrying out of business in Maranoa, Riverina-Darling and other electorates. I mentioned import parity petrol pricing. I am opposed to our parity pricing formula and I believe--
—Doug Anthony brought it in.

—I know that Doug Anthony brought it in. I was not very happy at the time he brought it in and I assure honourable members that I voiced my objection at the time to Doug Anthony and the Fraser Government. I still argue that it is not the right formula. I do not believe we should fix our price of fuel on the price asked by nomad Arabs in the desert who get together and rip out of us $30 or $40 a barrel for crude oil. Yet we agree with them, cap in hand, and adjust our price accordingly. When Keating became Treasurer-the greatest disaster ever to hit this nation-he floated the dollar and up went the price of our own fuel.
—And the dollar sinks.

—The dollar sinks 20c at least. It has gone down 25c since the dollar was floated. Of course, the price of fuel has gone up accordingly. I see the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) at the table. I put it to him that we cannot make gains. When the dollar depreciates those of us in export industries get a trading advantage against other countries. That is why our dollar is going downwards. But interest rates are going up and fuel prices are going up. The real price of money today is at least 12 per cent. I put it to the House that that is the most we have ever had to pay for money. If one wants to borrow $100,000 or more one will pay nearly 17 per cent interest today. The banks have put interest rates up 2 1/2 to 3 per cent in the last month. This Labor Government claims that we have only 5 per cent inflation. If we take five from 17, we get 12 per cent; and that is the real interest rate we are paying. It has never been higher. Although we have picked up something from the devaluation, the Government announced today that fuel prices have gone up 3.9c a litre, the greatest rip-off since we started driving motor vehicles and had to use fuel. We have never seen an increase of that magnitude. Of course, interest rates have gone up as well. I turn to farm costs. The great white leader, the Prime Minister, is meeting with the National Farmers Federation at this time. That is why Keating is not here. I hope he is meeting the farmers, otherwise I would expect him to be here. They are meeting tonight at 7.30.
—You are lucky he is not here.
—Guns or butter.

—Guns or butter, yes. At least the Government is meeting the farmers, but I would like to see some action. After today's meeting I would like to see the Government do something about tariffs, interest rates and fuel prices. I would like to see this Government give the farmers and small business people across this nation a fair go. I would like the Government to look at some of these rapidly increasing costs which it claims it is reducing but which are going through the roof.

The national highway program will provide unprecedented opportunities for the people who live in or visit the Hunter Valley. The improved road system will provide a major boost for the Hunter Valley's important tourist industry. The potential of our wine and tourist industries is virtually untapped. There is limitless potential. People are aware of this. There is not one detractor of the wonderful and innovative promotion being achieved by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Hon. John Brown. However, while agreeing that our roads are in need of improvement, the achievements of the Labor Minister for Transport are superb compared with the ineptitude and the neglect that characterised the coalition's handling of roads when it was in government. I make this point: In 1981-82, when we had a coalition Federal government, the amount spent on Federal local road grants was $161.6m The amount to be spent in 1985-86 is $257.7m, an increase of 59.5 per cent. In the last year of the Fraser Government $685m was spent on total Federal road grants. This year $1,245m will be spent, an increase of 81.8 per cent. I spoke in this House last week, and I will continue to speak in this House, of the disgraceful lack of sewerage in my electorate. That significant urban areas are without sewerage in this last quarter of the twentieth century is, as I have said before, a national scandal. The last genuine attempt to address the national sewerage backlog was the Sewerage Agreement Act in 1973 under the Whitlam Government's national sewerage program. In its last year of government a total of $118m was given to provide an essential facility to those people who live not in isolated farm houses but in urban areas and are denied this essential facility. I will not repeat my quip about Fraser denying people the opportunity to pull the chain, but let me say that Fraser just showed the concern he had for people who live in unsewered townships. We should bury our heads in shame. Due to the work of this Labor Government, there will be one chance-in October, at a national forum on infrastructure. We hope that that will do something to overcome the serious sewerage backlog.
