This Government has done marvellously in its efforts to create employment. It has performed brilliantly compared with the hopeless ineptitude of the Fraser Government. The Hawke Government's initiatives deserve to be lauded but it is essential that we keep up those efforts to get out of the abyss of despair into which we were plunged through the muganomics of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) while he was Treasurer. The Government is keeping up its efforts. Thankfully, in the Hunter electorate today the Federal Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the New South Wales Minister for Employment, the Hon. Bob Debus, announced the project involving the building of parks and community centres at Landcom estates. These Landcom estates in the Hunter region will be provided with much needed community facilities. These worthwhile developments will also create employment. There will be a total expenditure of $2.1m and 110 jobs will be created. We are seeing more money from this Government than we would have seen in a decade from the conservatives on the other side of this House.

I make mention of a further problem, one which is expanding and which requires vast expenditure if it is to be checked. However we look at the subject, there is no rational explanation of why Australia should have a housing problem. Yet in Australia 138,000 people are on the waiting list for Housing Commission homes. The cost of meeting that great need, at a cost of, say $50,000 per house, amounts to a staggering $6.9 billion. The Government has done well with such measures as the first home owners scheme but the housing problem remains a mammoth one which needs to be addressed urgently. The Federal and State governments must make a more genuine attempt to meet the housing needs of the people they represent. Years of government inaction have caused this situation. In this respect I am not talking about a Labor government, I am talking about a conservative government which has occupied the treasury bench for the greater part of this century since Federation. If the responsibility for the things that are missing to make our lives what they should be lies anywhere, honourable members opposite know where it lies. They should hang their heads in shame. Years of government inaction have left Australians with a housing problem second only to unemployment in magnitude and social cost.

It is a tragedy that drug abuse, crime and moral decay have caused our society to degenerate to a level which sees the virtual collapse of the family as a cohesive social unit. Instead we see the ascendancy of a general aimlessness and a loss of purpose which makes supported accommodation a growth industry. Recently there has been action in this House in an attempt to remedy that unfortunate state of affairs. Unfortunately, we live in a less than perfect society, a society where there is a booming need for crisis accommodation. Twenty years ago most members of this House had never heard of a refuge or a rape or crisis centre. What a tragedy it is that we now hear those words daily. It is pleasing that this Government is moving positively to address the need for supported accommodation. A program involving co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States is needed sorely because the problem of homelessness is nationwide. All States and the Northern Territory are in dire need of crisis and youth accommodation.

The Australian newspaper of 8 March this year cited a figure of more than 25,000 homeless youth in Australia with crisis centres and youth refuges unable to meet the growing demand-this in International Youth Year. There are young people today who, because of family breakdown, unemployment or other factors, are leading lives which can only be described as nightmarish. Their lives are frightening and the problems of youth homelessness are frightening. So enormous and complex are these problems that I have a great fear that although this Government is increasing funding by 100 per cent this year it will not be enough. It will serve only to attack the symptoms rather than the causes of homelessness.

We must recognise that homelessness is an expanding problem. Vast sums will be needed to check that expansion. In the electorate of Hunter we have stories which match those coming from other centres throughout the nation. It is necessary for the community to realise that the young homeless are not bums and dole bludgers. Certainly there are drug victims who need help but needing help also are those young people who are victims of emotional and sexual abuse and parental rejection. The media, the churches, the welfare workers and even members on the other side of this House recognise the need for crisis accommodation. Adequate food and shelter are fundamental to human rights and we must make every endeavour to ensure the provision of these basics for survival in life.

We do not want our young people, our women or any male to be forced to sleep in the streets. Every community must have crisis accommodation. It is not good enough when there is one centre for several communities, or none at all. We do not want to read stories such as those which appeared in the Sunday Mail or the Hobart Mercury this year about homeless youths sleeping in Life Line bins. Another such story appeared in the West Australian the following day. It told of homeless and distressed young boys and girls engaging in prostitution. Too often we read reports about needed crisis accommodation centres closing because of the shortage of funds. Never again must we read such reports.

I know that every member of this House is able to relate a gruesome, awesome and tragic story about a man, woman or child who has had an unmet need for supported accommodation assistance. In the Hunter electorate and in every other electorate people are doing magnificent work to alleviate the problem and the terror of homelessness, but willingness and strong arms are not enough without financial assistance. Governments must make sure that they do not fail those who are out in the field trying to create a better life for those whose need for help is desperate.

One of the parties to that agreement decided that it wanted to vary the details of the contract. I suppose that is completely appropriate if that partner to the agreement wishes to vary the context of the contract. For weeks we saw the Australian Government trying to assess its position. What would happen if there were problems in the Cook Islands and the United States were required to bring a nuclear-powered vessel to the area? There has never been a period in the history of the Commonwealth when any economic strategy applied by any government had such appalling results.

What it has been possible for this Government to implement in the relatively short period in which we have been in government-and I believe it is one of the major factors contributing to the incredible and outstanding economic success of this Government-has been precisely the prices and incomes accord that the honourable member for Mitchell believes should be abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government is a disaster.

—That prices and incomes accord has made it possible for this Government to provide an expansionary economic strategy, to bring about economic growth and at the same time to bring down inflation. It is completely unreasonable for members of the Opposition to make the claim, which they have repeatedly made and which was echoed a short time ago by way of a quite foolish interjection from one member of the Opposition, that this Government has in any way been deficient as far as its economic objectives or economic success are concerned. SPEECH.PARA: We need refer to nothing other than the national accounts figures for the December quarter. Real non-farm product, seasonally adjusted, grew by a strong 1.4 per cent in that quarter and provided total growth of 5.1 per cent over 1984. That is non-farm growth, or real economic growth in the non-farm sector. It is particularly relevant that in the first year of this Government, following those disastrous years of the Fraser Government-and the most disastrous of them all, the last year of the Fraser Government, when economic growth was negative, when Australia had gone into reverse, when the Australian economy, together with employment, were in states of free fall-we were able to achieve the highest level of growth that had been achieved in Australia in any post-war period and the highest level of growth of any member country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in the advanced Western world. Over the year we achieved an economic growth in real terms of 10 per cent, and year on year we achieved economic growth of 6 per cent. Of that 6 per cent 4 per cent only was in the non-farm sector. So this year there has been a further improvement when one sees that the real growth in the non-farm sector is running at a rate of about 5 per cent compared with 4 per cent in the first year of the Hawke Government. Therefore, the improvement continues and those quite outstanding results can be repeated over and over again.

I also want to make a quick reference to the fact that not only has this Government been outstandingly successful in its achievements as a result of a constructive, integrated, co-ordinated and sensible economic policy which it has implemented, but a Commonwealth Government has been prepared to accept for itself an economic discipline of a kind which has never previously been accepted. I refer to the trilogy-well, it started off as a trilogy but has now become a quintet. I shall refer to why I now call it a quintet. Everyone is aware, or should be aware, of the original trilogy. First, we said that we would not increase Commonwealth taxation revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product. That commitment was clearly given. Secondly, we undertook not to increase Commonwealth expenditure at a faster rate than economic growth. Thirdly, we undertook not to allow the deficit to grow as a percentage of GDP.

SPEECH.PARA: They were the first three undertakings given by the Prime Minister in the lead-up to the last election. Since then the Government, through the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), has decided to apply an even more rigid economic discipline to the approach we are taking to economic policy and general budgetary or fiscal strategy. We have now decided as well not only to ensure that the deficit does not grow as a proportion of GDP but, in addition, to reduce the deficit in nominal terms. This year we were budgeting for a deficit of about $6.7 billion. Even if we were to maintain that level of Budget deficit because of the increase in prices, it would represent a reduction in the deficit in real terms. We have decided to reduce it even further than that. Assuming that the present appearance of the economy and international economic factors remain essentially as they are at the moment and that there is no need for any type of crisis response to another situation, we will bring the Budget deficit for the next financial year in aggregate down to about $6 billion to $6.2 billion, I would imagine. That will make a substantial contribution to the preservation of confidence in the economy.

The last thing we have undertaken to do is to not allow the beneficial results to government revenue of the more recent depreciation to be used to reduce in any way or to ease the spending constraints that we have imposed on ourselves. Rather, those financial benefits to Commonwealth revenue from depreciation will be used either to reduce the deficit further or to reduce labour costs. In that connection I want to express a concern. The economic achievements of this Government have been more than substantial. They have been outstanding. I have doubts about what exactly motivates responses of that kind. I have said before that the facts speak for themselves and the facts undoubtedly indicate, in glowing terms, the outstanding results that this Government has been able to bring about as a result of the application of coherent, effective and, above all, successful economic policies.

I referred to the dumping of these rules on the poor old motorist with little regard for our unique demographic and meteorological conditions. I referred to the failure of governments to conduct cost impact studies and cost-benefit analyses, and a lack of regard for cost effective ratios.

SPEECH.PARA: We now appear to be entering the next stage in this costly farce. Once again the poor old Australian motorist will be the meat in the sandwich. Recent newspaper headlines have highlighted the introduction of unleaded petrol on to the Australian market. The decision to introduce a national policy for more stringent emission controls was taken in 1981 by agreement between State and Federal Transport Ministers. The policy calls for the introduction of unleaded petrol at service station outlets in July this year. After 1 January 1986 all new passenger vehicles will be fitted with catalytic converters and will be required to run exclusively on unleaded petrol. The decision to change over to unleaded petrol was made in response to concern expressed by health authorities and conservationist groups which claim that pollution levels in Australian cities are too high. Emissions of hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide from motor vehicles contribute to photochemical smog in the atmosphere.

Existing emission controls fitted to vehicles since 1976 are not performing adequately. However, a table of frequency of smog episodes, based on data obtained from the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the New South Wales State Pollution Control Commission and the Victorian Environment Protection Authority show that in 1983 in Los Angeles, where about 50 per cent of cars had catalytic converters fitted, more than 80 days of the 90-day summer season had at least one hour when the ozone level was greater than 0.12 parts per hundred million. The National Health and Medical Research Council set that 0.12 parts per million standard in 1979. It has suggested that this level not be exceeded more than once a year. However, a warning is not issued unless the ozone level reaches more than 0.25 parts per million.

According to the same table, in 1983 Sydney had approximately six days and Melbourne approximately 24 days with an ozone reading higher than 0.12 parts per million for one hour or more. While readings of this magnitude are not to be condoned, it is interesting to note that in Sydney since 1975, during the summer season the highest number of smoggy days peaked in 1977, with 40 days. Since that year Sydney has experienced fewer than 10 smoggy days in any one year. Melbourne's highest number of smoggy days per annum since 1974 was in 1983. In 1978 and 1981 there was only one day with an ozone reading above 0.1 parts per million. Los Angeles's lowest number of smoggy days during the nine-year period was 42 in 1983.

One could be forgiven for drawing the conclusion from these statistics that fitting motor vehicles with catalytic converters and the use of unleaded petrol have very little to do with ozone levels. It would seem that governments acted too hastily in imposing the changeover to unleaded petrol in Australia. No consideration appears to have been given to the vast areas of Australia where pollution levels do not even remotely approach this figure.
In my speech on a matter of public importance in 1979 I referred to this situation:

The problem is confined to a few square kilometres in the centres of our largest cities and all motoring Australians living and working outside those areas are asked to pay for a problem which is theirs neither in manufacture nor consumption. Motorists from all over Australia are carrying this heavy cost day in and day out for the benefit of those who live and work in the centres of metropolitan Melbourne and Sydney, and even then possibly to ease a problem which exists for a very few days in the year. The imposition of these emission controls is, in the main, a direct result of traffic congestion caused by poor inner city traffic management and a lack of efficient trans-central business networks.

Mark Grenning, the 1984 winner of the Committee for Economic Development of Australia prize for his thesis 'Australian Motor Vehicle Emission Policy 1970-96', alleges that policies chosen by bureaucrats and politicians were inefficient, that there had been an overstatement of our cities pollution problems, that inappropriate United States policies had been adopted and that there had been little consideration of alternative approaches. One recent media report states: 'Catalytic technology has been proven over ten years in the United States and Japan.' It may have been proven, but the question is whether it has been proven to be effective or ineffective.
Late last year Mr James Creal, President of the American Automobile Association, addressed the annual meeting of the Australian Automobile Association. Alluding to lead free petrol, he said:
With things going so well for you 'down under', why in the world would you want to follow our lead in matters as important as the environment?

Mr Creal went on to discuss some of the problems which occurred in the United States when lead free petrol was introduced and problems which are now current 10 years later. He said that there is still debate in the United States as to whether taking lead out of one grade of petrol was a significant ecological benefit. Looking at the Los Angeles pollution levels, it would appear that it was not. Mr Creal went on to say that there were still questions as to the technology involved in cars needing unleaded petrol and that there were concerns about unleaded fuel as far as availability, price and quality were concerned. He warned about the potential for misfuelling and vehicle tampering and the consequent lowering of environmental expectations from these actions.

A recent headline in the Age stated that there will be a maximum fine of $800 for deliberate use of leaded petrol in vehicles designed to take unleaded petrol. Maybe this pressure on the hip pocket nerve will reduce the incidence of this practice in Australia.

Liquid organic lead alkyls are added to petrol to increase its octane rating. Lead additives allow high quality petrol to be produced with a minimum of refining, thereby saving Australia many millions of barrels of crude oil every year. Lead will be removed from petrol because it will destroy the metals used in manufacturing the catalytic converters. Government authorities determined the optimum octane rating for Australian unleaded petrol as 92. Vehicles manufactured after the January 1986 deadline will have lower compression ratios than present vehicles.

It is interesting to note that in America the octane rating had to be lifted from the original 91 to 96 because of complaints regarding engine knocking. As the Australian decision was partially based on the need to cut down on the consumption of crude oil in the refineries and to cut down on costs, it seems likely that it was badly conceived. Australian motorists may ultimately have to pay more for their unleaded petrol in order to regain the level of vehicle performance being currently experienced. It does nothing to increase our confidence to read in the December 1984 issue of the Institute of Training Standards magazine:

The new standard, AS 1876.2-Unleaded Petrol, is concerned primarily with the performance of unleaded petrol, particularly in terms of its anti-knock value. Requirements for properties such as distillation range and vapour pressure have not been specified because of the wide range of climatic conditions encountered across Australia and the necessity of varying these properties according to season and location.

The original estimated cost of a catalytic converter was $250. That estimate has now risen to $400 and some manufacturers have suggested $750. According to the Petroleum Gazette of spring 1984 these converters are:
. . . intended to last the life of the vehicle and should need no maintenance.
Mr Creal, in his address to the Australian Automobile Association said:

We're now into the third generation of catalytic converters. Those on late-model US vehicles are capable of reducing not only carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon emissions, but also oxides of nitrogen which contribute to urban smog. Some believe catalytic converters forced US automakers into the computer age. To control emissions, some newer US cars are now equipped with computerised fuel injection, oxygen censors, electronic readouts and diagnostic capabilities. Though sophisticated, they are still fragile. And too many motorists-perhaps two of every dozen-drive round with their catalysts totally destroyed from fuel-switching or improper engine maintenance.
We are seeing signs, too, that new catalysts may last no longer than 30,000 miles, instead of the 50,000-mile warranties they carry.

American experience has seen a move to three-way converters, which are more expensive and more complicated than those being used now. Platinum, rhodium and palladium, which are used in manufacturing converters, are supplied primarily by South Africa and the Soviet Union. It is not beyond the realms of possibility that greater demand for these metals will lead to an increased price for them.

A recent engineering report states that no catalyst so far in service lasts more than about 30 minutes at speeds in excess of 125 kilometres per hour. Whilst I acknowledge that the speed limit on Australian roads is 100 kilometres per hour, studies have shown that speeds on the open highway are generally above the posted speed limit and that towing of caravans, horse floats and boats, making the engine work harder, is commonplace. One source quotes examination of a catalyst which had failed after about 2,000 kilometres at 125 kilometres per hour.

In the United States new emission testing equipment must be installed at all service stations as present emission measuring systems are inadequate. The New Jersey Department of Environment Protection reports about a 25 per cent failure in catalysts. The catalysts have been found to suffer from melt-down or casing failures. The melt-down is caused by the hydrocarbon part of the catalyst detecting a high level of unburnt hydrocarbon and attempting to deal with it. This causes excessively high temperature which in turn burns out the inner casing even when it is of stainless high temperature steel.

The condition can occur for a number of reasons, including spark plug failure, incorrect mixture, failure of the oxygen sensor or a failed air cleaner. When catalyst failure is detected, the average catalyst replacement cost is about $US300, plus tax, plus labour. The actual air pollution figures in New Jersey are not showing an improvement. In fact, ozone levels are increasing and fuel consumption by new cars has increased over that being experienced prior to the introduction of emission controls. The possibility of ignition advance is negated by the fact that drivers in New Jersey do not appreciate a knocking engine, any more than I expect Australian motorists do.

There is a problem with fuel quality in the United States. Uncontrolled use of methanol has occurred and the oil companies use it as blending stock without regulation. As there is a growing demand for unleaded super and other high quality unleaded gasolines there is a growing temptation to use even more methanol to boost octane at the expense of other qualities. The cost of methanol is well below the cost of conventional fuel and it can be purchased from many sources.

Although data on fuel blending is supposed to be supplied on a continuous basis to the United States Environment Protection Agency for comparison tests, information is not supplied by jobbing blenders or corner garages. With the addition of only 12 per cent methanol, the fuel creates drivability problems which encourage motorists to top up with other fuels, including leaded fuel. The problems involved with the use of unleaded petrol are legion.

To get back to our friend Mr Creal, why would we want to follow the lead of the United States in this matter? In 1980 the Committee on Motor Vehicle Emissions, on whose report the unleaded petrol decision was based, estimated that the cost of changeover to catalytic converters and unleaded petrol would cost the nation $1,000m for the 10 years from 1986 to 1996. About half this is the cost of the conversion of facilities and half is for the motorist. All in all, it is proving a most expensive exercise with a doubtful result.

A recent report by the Committee of Common Market Automobile Constructors to the European Economic Community Commission claims that high compression, lean-burn engines are better than catalytic converters for reducing harmful exhaust emissions. The submission points out that the European air quality in 1982 was very similar to that in the United States despite the use of catalysts and stringent emission control in that country. The estimated annual cost of unleaded petrol to motorists within the EEC would top $US2,000m with an increase in annual energy consumption of more than four million tonnes of crude oil equivalent.

The decision to change to unleaded petrol in Australia cannot now be revoked. However, it is important that we take heed of the lessons we have learned. Future environmental issues must be addressed with objectivity and decisions must be made after consideration of reasoned and reasonable advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking in support of the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1984-85 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1984-85 gives me the opportunity to express a number of concerns which I have in relation to the social, political and economic issues which affect young people. In this respect, I was most impressed by the recent policy response produced by the Youth Affairs Council of Australia, the recommendations of which I will draw to the attention of honourable members later in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage there is a matter in relation to the policies of the Federal Government which I wish to cover. I would like to express my particular support for the Federal Australian Labor Party Caucus decision not to reintroduce tertiary education fees-not that I have any particular doubt about the decision, because the Federal platform of the Australian Labor Party makes the matter very clear. It appears to me that both the media and the Opposition members of this House are unaware of the pledge which Labor parliamentarians make to uphold the policies contained in the Party platform. Of course, it is true that where the policy is broadly defined or there is a reasonable time frame for implementation, the Government has some flexibility in carrying out any specific policy. But when the policy is clear, as was the case with tertiary education fees, I was puzzled about the reasons for the media speculation and, indeed, even the need for subsequent Caucus debate.

The Party platform states quite unequivocally that a Labor government will 'maintain the provision of free tertiary education'. It underlines that statement by explicitly stating that in particular a Labor government will 'provide post-secondary education without fees'. I take this opportunity to point out to the media, to the Opposition and to the public in general that when any particular Party policy is explicitly stated in the current Party platform it is out of place to speculate that the Government would not adhere to that policy in view of the pledge which all Labor parliamentarians make when they accept nomination as a Labor Party candidate for the Federal Parliament.

I would now like to proceed to a discussion of the main concerns that I have about the future for young people in Australia. I commend the Government on its foresight in appointing the Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs under the chairmanship of Peter Kirby. The Committee was required to assess the extent to which the range of training and work experience programs inherited from the previous Government meet the labour market objectives of the present Government and make recommendations for necessary improvements. At the same time as the Kirby report was released, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development also produced a report entitled 'A Review of Youth Policies' which largely paralleled the findings of the Kirby report. However, one of the main problems with the Kirby report was that its terms of reference restricted the members of the Committee to dealing with labour market programs only. The report dealt hardly at all with the more crucial issue of job creation. However, there is no doubt that the report does provide a useful basic approach on which a comprehensive approach to unemployment can be built.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very thorough.

—I thank the honourable member for that comment. A major recommendation of the Kirby report was the recommendation that the community youth support scheme be developed into a permanent Australian youth service. As recommended in the report, the Government is currently consulting widely with all the government and non-government bodies involved in youth affairs. The Government is to be commended for taking such swift action on a proposal which has wide ramifications for the future development of youth affairs in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Kirby report analyses the problems of joblessness in Australia and indicates the need for young people to become better educated. Unfortunately, it is in this part of the report that there emerges the failure, as I see it, to grapple with the real problem of unemployment resulting from a lack of job opportunities. There is no doubt that our young people need to participate in a wide variety of educational programs at secondary and tertiary level, thus enabling them to better face the complexities of our modern society; but a greater participation in education of itself will not provide job opportunities, only government intervention to assist our manufacturing sector, in particular to restructure old industries and to create new industries, will provide new jobs.

As I have said in this House on a number of occasions, the industry development plan of the metal workers unions points the way for the Government, and I am hopeful of a positive response from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in respect of the recommendations of that plan. It is not my intention in this appropriations debate to go through all the recommendations of the Kirby report; I would only note here that the traineeship scheme, as recommended by the Committee, involves proposed extensions to the present training system. In my view, the level of training wages for participants in the scheme cannot be divorced from the wages of all other trainees. There must be a commitment to ensure that all trainees receive a level of income adequate to provide a reasonable standard of living. In a number of respects the proposed scheme will not be satisfactory to the union movement, not only because of the proposed dilution of wages but also because of the short term nature of the proposed traineeships.

With the rapidly changing life-styles and work technology of the late twentieth century, it is vital that any form of youth training recognise the need for flexibility and a broad base of skills. Such skills must include an ability to adapt not only to occupational needs but also to rapidly changing social structures. Leisure, for example, will undoubtedly become a major pursuit of people in the twenty-first century and unless we want to produce a generation of work-oriented psychotics our education system must recognise the need to train for leisure.

I turn now to the youth policy report of the Youth Affairs Council of Australia which I mentioned earlier in this speech. The YACA has proposed a national youth employment strategy with the three main components: First, economic assistance to employers; secondly, public authority youth employment quotas; and, thirdly, a national job generation program. I commend the YACA youth strategy to the House and refer more directly to the main components of that strategy. Economic assistance to employers is already provided by the Federal Government through a wide range of direct and indirect subsidies. Some $150m in direct employment subsidies will be provided in the 1984-85 financial year. I support the view of the YACA that, instead of this funding being used for short term jobs, it should be used to facilitate the development of full time jobs. Also, some $1,053m is provided in the 1984-85 financial year for indirect subsidies to specific industries. The strategy proposes a 'jobs audit' whereby the employment goals of each subsidy are identified and the recipients required to show that the subsidy has resulted in an increase in jobs. This would take place within an industry planning framework of support for future job generation.

Existing Commonwealth employment practices have resulted in a significant decline in the employment of young people employed in Commonwealth departments and public authorities. The Bureau of Labour Market Research has shown that 70,000 additional young people would have been employed within the public sector in 1981 if the public sector had maintained its share of the employment market over the preceding 10 years. It is notable that the draft Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development review of Australian youth policies contained a recommendation that Australian authorities should adopt policies of positive discrimination in favour of young people, but it would appear that this recommendation was deleted from the final report.

If that deletion was made, it was most unfortunate. I support the call of the YACA for the Federal Government to establish annual targets for youth employment within the Public Service and that the Government use the program of funding and grants to State and Territory governments and semi-government authorities to adopt policies of positive discrimination in favour of young people. Of course, such a policy must be combined with a policy of early retirement for all Public Service employees. In this respect the introduction of a national superannuation scheme, which I know has the support of some Minister in the Government, is long overdue.

Finally, the YACA national youth employment strategy calls for a national job generation program. The proposal is that the community employment program be upgraded and developed into a new job generation program. The program would involve the creation of economic development projects specifically designed to generate worthwhile permanent jobs. Community employment committees could be created at a regional level, comprising representatives of local employers, community and service groups, local union delegates and young people from CYSS-the community youth support scheme-groups or schools, with the task of researching, developing and providing viable employment generation programs.

The funding for the programs would be provided by a national job generation fund which would be funded by Commonwealth and State governments, based on a formula which takes into account the level of unemployment in the region concerned. The national job generation fund would provide capital, employment subsidies or grants, depending upon the nature of the project. The community employment committees would of course, need to be provided with administrative and professional support by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I commend the Youth Affairs Council of Australia for its initiative in producing a most comprehensive youth policy report and trust that the Government will give it full consideration and, perhaps, even anticipate the recommendations by funding some of the proposals within the framework of the Appropriation Bills which we are debating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the consequences of the Government's proposition that Additional Estimates totalling $564m be approved by this Parliament. We have just listened to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who extolled a lot of the virtues of what might be described as, yet again, the promises of euphoria for a section of the community. I regard this contribution, and many of the others made in the debate, only as a re-run of the charisma approach of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who for so long now has used nothing but subterfuge to extol a collapse of this country's economic status and who has, of course, denied this country and its young people the kind of opportunities that the honourable member for La Trobe now advocates.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind him that in the election campaign only six months ago a definite promise was made to the unemployed that there would be some funding for small business to enable applicants to establish businesses of their own as an alternative to unemployment. I ask the honourable member for La Trobe: What happened to that promise that was to help young people who had a proposition to put? The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is now very carefully back-pedalling on the promise. Anyone who inquires about it gets a stereotype answer which says: 'We have not yet worked the scheme out. We have not yet reached the stage where it can be proposed for implementation. You will have to think again. Sometime in the future we might reach that stage'. So we go through the litany of broken promises. Yet, speaker after speaker on the Government side has painted a rosy picture of what might be done in the immediate future in so many directions. What has happened to the charisma of the Prime Minister in terms of real action? We do not see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have created jobs.

—The honourable member comes right in and says: 'We have created jobs'. How about looking at the statistics as to the real deficiencies compared with the promises? We are not even halfway towards the target offered to the people of this country. Yet we find that funding for the community employment program has virtually dried up until the next Budget. The Government is just fooling the people by saying that there are more jobs and there are still more to come, because that is far from the truth. A very swift about turn is occurring in many directions. We had it last week in terms of the home grants scheme. There was a reduction of $1,000 in the top ceiling and graduated reduction from that ceiling. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has had to prune back road funding. Minister after Minister has told us, as we heard in Question Time even today, that it is not possible to provide for all of the undertakings that were given by the Government which occupies the front bench at present.
—Petrol goes up all the time too.

—My colleague reminds me about the promise on petrol. The election campaign promise was that the price of petrol would be reduced by at least 2c a litre. Since the election the price has not stopped going up. Today we heard the decision of the Government to take it up at least another 3.5c.
—How much?

—The price may go up by 3.9c a litre. That is yet another broken promise. I want to refer to a particular aspect of the pro- position before us; that is, the provision of funds to a range of departments so they are able to carry on until the Budget. We heard nothing in the speech which was made to the House when the Bills were introduced that gave any hope at all for areas of real hardship within the community. I am concerned particularly about primary industry. There was a debate about that subject earlier today. I refer to a letter which I received from the Prime Minister concerning the sugar industry. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The outcome of those discussions . . . was an agreement to form a tripartite working party comprising representatives from Commonwealth and Queensland governments and the industry. The charter of the working party is to develop a sugar industry plan in the next 100 days . . .

My approach to the Prime Minister was in relation to the problems confronting the industry in New South Wales. Yet the reply I received totally ignored the industry in New South Wales. Of course, there is a very positive association between the New South Wales industry and the Queensland industry. I am sure that there will be a recognition of New South Wales, but why is this not acknowledged by the Federal Government through the Prime Minister in his response to approaches that are made on this subject? Today I received a very interesting letter from a constituent which said:
I am extremely worried about Australia's future and I am at long last getting off my apathetic backside and writing letters of protest to this Government's socialist politicians.
I think that some sections of the letter are worthy of mention in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are getting a lot of these.
—From Doug Anthony.

—If the honourable member wants to know the constituent's name I will be very glad to furnish it to him. He can establish the authenticity of the letter. I do not intend to use a name in this House. If the honourable member sees me after the debate I will be glad to let him have the information. The letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Hawke, You are not the same man Australians voted for. You've lost your charm, popularity and credibility. Your 75% popularity did'nt last long. Why is your government stuffing up this country? We are really going to the dogs.

Before the elections I saw you on the Mike Walsh Show, and you said that all rural industries would need to have government assistance as the rural industry was vital to the economy of Australia and their exports were worth 50% odd of our total export market. It will be my job, when I am returned to power, to convince city people that we have to rely on and assist our rural industries. My government is for the good of all Australians.
Those were the words of the Prime Minister on the Mike Walsh Show. They will be remembered very clearly by most people in the rural areas of Australia. My constituent continued:

On election night after you were voted in by a reduced margin, in your victory speech you said you would work for the betterment of all Australians, whether we voted for you or not, and emphasised all Australians.
I quote a further section of the letter which came to me:

My taxable income last year was nil-I paid no tax-No Tax Payable and no refund due-it said on the form, and it will be the same this year. Therefore, I am not doing my bit towards the economy of my country. There are hundreds of thousands of Australians wanting to work and pay tax and help this so-called lucky country to the prosperity it deserves, but we are going down the gurgler further every day.
Farmers being the backbone of a country is no longer true, we are an endangered species.
I think that is a pretty pertinent comment. The letter went on:

We do not have 35-hour working weeks, overtime, flexidays, holiday pay or superannuation. We are downright hard working and caring people, who love and care for our way of life, living off the land. We are not Pitt Street farmers.

I am tired of hearing, tighten your belt, economise, you need to have a new infrastructure within your industry, get big or get out. What is going to happen to the little bloke who worked his guts out over the years, making a living off the land and then through no fault of his own is forced off his land he loves and cares for? What does the future hold for him? The best offer I can see for him is on the end of the line at the CES office and the dole. My personality, attitude and faith has changed from being a happy go lucky optimist to a cynical pessimist and that upsets me greatly. It has been widely reported that the sugar industry is the most efficiently controlled industry in Australia. Well, what chance have other industries got when we have no chance?
The letter went on to refer to some personal aspects of family difficulties. I conclude the reference to this constituent's approach:

Because I am an endangered species farmer and have property an a nil income, I am not eligible for social service. In the meantime I will live on fresh air and hope. Hope of some sanity for the survival and prosperity of the rural industries of Australia.

I believe that typifies the real problem confronting so many people across Australia today. There have been many references in the debates in this House since this session began about the iniquitous assets test and its effect on rural Australia. I could cite yet another example of the consequences of that test-not just one but dozens which have reached me in recent weeks.

Tonight, in considering the proposition which the Government puts before the House, we have to be mindful of the consequences of the approval that will be given for the extra expenditure. We face one of the toughest, undoubtedly worrying, economic situations that this country has experienced since well before the 1930s. If one analyses the consequences of the dilemma that is facing so many sections of Australian industry and primary industry today, there is no doubt at all that in relation to the tax summit and what will flow from it one will find the failure of the Government to identify precisely what is policy will be. What pretence we heard this afternoon when the Prime Minister answered a question and said that there will be several propositions and some accord as to what will finally be done. What arrant humbug. If the Cabinet and the Government of this country do not have an economic policy at present, heaven help all of us. But I fear that that is exactly the position, that there is no policy, no determination as to what should and should not happen. Is it any wonder that the dollar is slumping? Is it any wonder that there is concern in so many sections of industry? Is it any wonder that Australia is facing a very gloomy winter in the immediate few months?

I turn now to a few remaining points that I want particularly to make. This appropriation provides funds for a range of propositions. One is to provide additional funds-no less than $12.2m-for the Department of Communications. I do not know what that will be expected to finance but I hope that the Government will look seriously at expenditure by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. We find today the most idiotic approach to broadcasting and public affairs in this country. The trend represented by the National, the new news program, is ludicrous in the extreme. No longer is there a firm and positive news bulletin. Country areas have lost 50 per cent of the normal regional news services. They are now integrated with the State news bulletins. There is no regular evening television news programs in rural areas. That service has been eliminated or reduced to once or twice a week-a quite impossible situation.

Let us think of some of the implications of the spending that has gone on in this period of real economic stringency by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Dedicated people who have been there for decades have done a fine job and built up a reputation, and this has been taken away overnight by newcomers. Someone who has been in this country for four years has been put in charge of the national news program. Someone else who has been here from another country for a year and a half or so has completely overturned the whole process of the ABC's programming and the content of that programming.

I refer in particular to what I regard as a scurrilous approach to this nation's heritage and status, and to the implications of that approach. I refer to two programs that are to be held, one on Anzac eve and one on Anzac night. On Anzac eve an Open File program is to pose the question: 'Whose flag is that?'. Why choose Anzac eve for a cynical approach to the matter of our national traditions and in particular the Australian national flag? I am sure that that program will do nothing more than denigrate the feelings of so many of those loyal Australians who fought for this country and for its survival. Of course, it will be intended to influence young people who do not have a recollection of those rather terrible days that we will acknowledge on Anzac day. Then, on Anzac night, what will we get? We will get a program entitled The Unnecessary War, screening on ABC television at 7.30 p.m. It will suggest that during the last few months of World War II Australian troops in the Pacific, in Papua-New Guinea, Bougainville and Borneo, were fighting a series of battles which need never have been fought. I put it to this Government that this is a reflection on its own Party because that Party was in office at that time. The Australian Labor Party's great hero, John Curtin, was Prime Minister. Are honourable members opposite going to take some of the blame and some of the odium connected with this program, which undoubtedly will be a real reflection on the strategies and policy decisions of both the Government and its military advisers at the time? They choose Anzac night for this scurrilous attack.

I recall that we have experienced similar situations on previous Anzac nights. I suggest that honourable members look back one or two years to check which programs were shown. I believe that if we are to provide additional expenditure in this appropriation for the Department of Communications, the least the Government could do is to try to bring some decency to the approach of the ABC on these two programs that are to be screened on Anzac eve and Anzac night. This House should be looking with real scrutiny at this proposition for the expenditure of additional funds to meet the requirements of government between now and the forthcoming Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that this Government, on coming to office, inherited an economy with massive structural difficulties. By any measure the performance of the Government since that time has been very good. Indeed, the inflation rate has been halved, growth has been restored, unemployment has fallen and employment has grown substantially. In just 22 months, 341,000 jobs have been created and the Government is well on target to create half a million jobs in its first three years in office. Additionally, there are very encouraging signs in the home building industry, car registrations and retail activity, and also the Government has embarked on restructuring programs in the steel industry and the motor vehicle building industry. This is only a start.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I shall address one of the structural problems. Again, it has been inherited by this Government but it is, perhaps, one of the most important in that it faces us all. I refer to the problem of youth unemployment. When we came to office 30 per cent of our 15 to 19 year olds were unemployed. The figure is more respectable now, at 25 per cent, but I am sure that honourable members on both sides would agree that it is far from optimal. This issue was canvassed in the Age today. While I disagree with the editorial view with regard to the pace at which the Government is pursuing this problem, there are two excerpts from that editorial which I think have merit. The first states:
. . . one in four young people cannot get a job, and that is not a solid foundation on which to build a society.
I believe that all of us would agree with that comment. The second and perhaps the most relevant aspect of that editorial reads:
We can no longer afford to talk about the problem. Imaginative policies must be introduced which will give young people some long-term hope.

Again, I believe that all people in this House would endorse that view. During the last 15 years there have been long term and permanent changes in the labour market and the organisation of work which has progressively excluded teenagers from full time employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have never listened to so much drivel--
—There is no point of order.

—I am delighted that so many of my colleagues are here to listen tonight as this is, of course, an issue of great importance. Between August 1970 and August 1984 full time employment for teenagers fell by 156,000. In August 1970 52.7 per cent of teenagers had full time employment. By August 1984 33.6 per cent of teenagers had full time employment. There were improvements in part time employment for teenagers but the vast majority of these were in full time education. Within the Public Service the number of appointments for teenagers and young people fell substantially.

SPEECH.PARA: Even sustained growth will not reverse this trend. During the second half of the 1970s the then Government started to recognise the difficulty but, as usual, its response was ad hoc and piecemeal. The special youth employment training program had, and still has, merit but, of course, there was little concern in that program for the level and quality of training it provided. The community youth support scheme was introduced and grudgingly maintained. Trade training programs, for instance the Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full-time training, were introduced and developed to support apprenticeship schemes and in 1979, just before an election, we had the school to work transition program. All of these programs had a place. All had value. All helped but they were ad hoc programs, not co-ordinated, and they showed no vision. The numbers of youth unemployed continued to grow.

A crisis now existed in youth unemployment. It was only the trade training programs which really improved the position of these young people within the labour market. The challenge which we must face now is to supply the opportunity for those young people to gain the skills necessary for them to fit within the labour market. Every young person needs a chance to acquire those skills. A recent Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd poll indicated very clearly that amongst young people unemployment was the major issue. They wanted work and help to get it.

What about Australia's performance compared with that of other countries? In Austria, where the population is exactly half that of Australia, there are 180,000 trainees. In Australia, alas, we have only 140,000 apprentices and trainees. It has been shown in countries such as West Germany, Switzerland, Sweden and Austria that small businesses are providing almost 50 per cent of those jobs and traineeships. The Kirby report unashamedly opts for employment based vocational training schemes. I believe the Government has already started to move in the correct direction. The participation and equity program increased the post-compulsory education participation rate and the structural changes within schools make formal education more attractive and relevant. A review of the youth income support scheme is being undertaken. In adopting the recommendations of the Kirby report, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report and the Bureau of Labour Market Research report this Government will be heading towards traineeship employment schemes.

The Office of Youth Affairs has been moved to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the community employment scheme has broken the cycle for many long term unemployed people. The Government's task is to provide leadership but the whole community is responsible for this problem. It is too simplistic to say, as do our opponents time and again, that the answer is to deregulate youth wages. That would, to a degree, displace adult workers. It would not solve structural problems and certainly would not improve the skills of our young people. It would not involve the whole community. The former Government talked about deregulating. It wanted to deregulate the airlines and we got that strait-jacket called the two-airline agreement. The former Government talked about deregulating financial structures and it failed. It talked about attacking Telecom Australia with deregulation. It sounded good, it sounded Gucci, but the Government never had the guts to do it and it never delivered.

It is my belief that what we need are not the tired solutions of the past but an independent manpower task force, an authority for employment and training, something which is detached but which has long term goals. We need an authority which is flexible, which has discretionary powers and a mandate for a trainee policy. We need tripartite representation on that board and we need to set ourselves targets now that we can achieve in the foreseeable future. The Kirby report suggests 75,000 trainees is attainable by 1988. We need such an authority set up so that we can market and deliver those results. Youth employment needs to be co-ordinated with early retirement, permanent part time work, job sharing and the youth allowance restructuring which is being undertaken. At the cornerstone we need the ethos that we will provide for all school leavers an opportunity for further education, training and employment. We need to decentralise the decisions so that they can be taken at a community and local level.

Perhaps our apprentice schemes are too inflexible. Perhaps we need to look at them. Perhaps we need to talk with small employers at the local level who can employ someone for three days a week who can then be trained for the remaining two days. Perhaps we need to slash some of the red tape that presently exists. One of the possibilities is forgoing the holiday loading for trainees. Perhaps we need to look at the workers' compensation arrangements that can be made between small groups. Group schemes can be set up. Certainly, State costs and charges such as payroll tax discriminate against employment and need to be reassessed.

I do not believe that one in four of our young Australians are not worth the effort. I do not believe that one in 10 or one in 20 are not worth the effort. We must have a sense of purpose and we have to break free from some of the structures which are choking us and our initiative, no matter how well we may be intentioned. There is a crisis in youth employment. Our opponents have failed but, unfortunately, as a result Australia is failing. It is not a time for petty point scoring. There is no purpose in that. We are all responsible. We must invest in our young people. They deserve a chance and we have to give them that chance.

Michelle Grattan, reporting in the Age newspaper of 16 April 1985, along with a number of other journalists, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Government sources said that family allowances were the only significant social security area under threat from the Cabinet razor gang.

A number of newspaper reports spoke of potential changes to the family allowance scheme. They have covered a very wide range. When one reads a newspaper report, under a Labor government, stating that government sources say something, one can be sure that it could come from anyone from the Prime Minister down. Without a doubt the Cabinet Expenditure Review Committee has been considering a number of potential changes. The principles involved in the family allowance are very profound. I look forward to comments that some of the women members of the Government might make on the subject of the principles of the family allowance as a payment to women for the role of mothering. It is not a welfare payment. It never was described as such and it never was intended to be such. The proposals for change fall into five categories. One is that the family allowance be taxed. Another is that it be means tested. A third is that there be a flat rate, that is the same rate for every child in the family regardless of the number of children. A fourth suggestion is that it might be removed for dependent student children over the age of 16 years. The fifth proposal is that the first child may not qualify for the family allowance. I will take the last point first.

It was back in 1951 that the Menzies Government extended child endowment to the first child in the family. That was welcomed at the time. It has never been suggested that it was anything other than a proper move. Now, 34 years later, a Labor government is looking at turning back the clock. Of course, it should be remembered that it was not Federal Labor governments that introduced or extended child endowment. In the first place it was introduced under a Menzies Government. In the second place it was extended to the first child in the family by a Menzies Government. The very substantial reform of family allowances happened in 1976 under the Fraser Government. One of the reforms that took place in 1976 was the extension of the family allowance to dependent student children between the ages of 16 and 25 years. TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a welfare payment.

—As the honourable member for Dawson says, it is not a welfare payment. I shall return to previous views of government members on this subject as recorded in Hansard of time past. Those honourable members seem to have forgotten it. Certainly there are a number of Government members who appear to be unaware that they were views ever expressed by members of the Labor Party in this Parliament. I shall remind them of it shortly. If time does not permit me to do that this evening I shall do so when the debate resumes.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that should be made about the family allowance is that it is paid to the mother of children. There are some exceptions where, for example, the mother is dead or, if the parents of the children are divorced, the father has custody. Overwhelmingly the allowance is paid to the mother. It was introduced as some recognition-not a full recognition-of the value of the mothering role and the contribution that anyone who is rearing children makes to society. I hasten to add that when I use the term 'mothering role' I use it in its broadest possible sense and obviously I extend it to fathers who are raising their children without the support of the children's mother. The first issue--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a sexist term?

—I do not consider it to be a sexist term but a useful non-generic term. The first point concerns the issue of taxing. This is where the Government will stir up a hornet's nest for itself. The great issue that arises in relation to any proposal to tax family allowances is to decide against whose income it is to be taxed. Is the family allowance to be taxed only according to the income of the person receiving it? As I have said, in most cases that is the mother and in most cases the mothers of dependent children either earn no other income or else earn a small income. The percentage of married women with dependent children in the work force who derive a full income and a substantial income from working is very small indeed. Most have a very small income. I am aware that this proposal was looked at by the Fraser Government. The figures were done. The information that came forward was that--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am stating a fact which Government members need to know about because otherwise they will proceed in total ignorance. Perhaps they ought to ask some of their Ministers about this in their Caucus. The facts are that if the family allowance were taxed according only to the income of the person receiving the family allowance the reduction in expenditure that the Government would incur would be negligible. That is no way to reduce the Budget. However, a very serious anomaly arises in relation to this. It is possible in the case of large families for a woman in receipt of only the family allowance in fact to cross the tax threshold by virtue of the payments she receives under that allowance. Therefore, a payment which is not considered excessive and which, on all the principles on which it was established and has been continued-that is a payment for the mothering role-is to be reduced simply because that woman is the mother of a large number of children. That is totally iniquitous.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to correct a misapprehension in regard to the living conditions of black South Africans on the part of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). I do so because I find this opinion reflected too often in the general community. Earlier this evening the honourable member said that the blacks in South Africa have better standards of living than blacks in any other African country. He based his comments on a trip he made to South Africa in late 1983. He said that people should go there to see how black South Africans live. I, in company with two other Government members, went to South Africa at the same time as the honourable member for Maranoa. We broke away from the government guides and had a look for ourselves to see just how black South Africans were living.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer specifically to one instance-that is, the Crossroads shanty town in Cape Town. Late in 1983 the unofficial estimate of the number of inhabitants was 45,000. The official estimate was 25,000 and it has since been confirmed that there are 100,000 black African people collected together in a conglomeration of humpies and hovels in the centre of beautiful Cape Town. They are living in homes made of galvanised iron, bits of sacking and bits of black plastic. They are there because it is illegal for them to be with their families anywhere else in South Africa. Only a few blocks away there are homes that are certainly reminiscent of more affluent suburban areas in Australia. Maybe the honourable member saw those homes. But the black Africans to whom I refer were not living there.

The shanty town was full of women and children who had trekked and travelled by bus from so-called homelands to be with their menfolk. The men were working in Cape Town because there was no work in the so-called homelands to which they had been forced to go by the South African Government. I was told of men who had contracts lasting 11 months having to live in the infamous and unhygienic men's single quarters, which are big concrete blocks without drainage or sewerage. It was the only place in which they could legally live. This hovel area in which 100,000 people lived was crowded. The women and children were living with the sick and the aged in the homelands. They found living by themselves too much, and they came down to join their menfolk. But it was illegal for them to be there, so they squatted in this area. It is not like a squatter's town in Australia because they were not allowed to move out, no matter what wage their husband earned. They were not allowed to set up a home in Cape Town.

I went with the wife of an Anglican priest. We spoke to organisations-the United Democratic Front, the Black Sash and different churches-and they reiterated the conditions that we saw there. It was appalling. Women with babies were put into prison after regular raids to show that they should not legally be there. We were told that some black South Africans working in the vineyards were better off. They were paid by the tot system. The tot system was mentioned by a number of different people. At the age of 12 people are put to work in the vineyards and part of the payment is a tot of wine three times a day. By the time they are 22 they are confirmed alcoholics and cannot move away from the white masters because they are secure only on those vineyards.

When I returned to Australia I issued a Press statement in which I outlined some of these problems and many more. I have photographs and much written matter to confirm them. It was not picked up. People from the Press rang me and said: 'That is not true'. They had been to South Africa three weeks previously. They had seen the white area and had not seen how these many black people lived. There are such areas right across South Africa. It does not matter how well some members of this House may think the black South Africans who are in service and who have a home live. It does not justify the appalling conditions. The oppression had nothing to do with black and white; it was a case of have and have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of honourable members the plight of Phillip Island's fairy penguins. My interest is not recent. My family has given land to the penguin parade. I have served as chairman of the committee of management of the penguin parade and during that time I initiated a research program into penguins that is unique in Australia. The penguin is the third largest international tourist attraction in Australia, attracting 80,000 international tourists per annum out of a total of 300,000 visitors. The future of the parade is now in doubt. There is a severe food shortage, the causes of which are largely unknown. The mortality rate of chicks has increased to 80 per cent and so bad is the situation that the management of the parade has had to institute hand feeding of chicks. The research work to date has been land-based and certainly an excellent program has been in place. I pay tribute to the work of Peter Dann, the research biologist, and Professor Mike Cullen of Monash University. But what is needed now is research into food sources, food chains and the localities of such sources of food.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a national issue for four reasons. Firstly, the fisheries are within Commonwealth waters and are an important primary industry. Secondly, the tourist industry is a major export earner in this country and we need every dollar that we can earn in terms of exports in view of the fate of the Australian dollar under the socialist Government that is currently in power. Thirdly, the national parks have an involvement in the management of the parade and, fourthly, over $1m of Commonwealth and State money is being provided for the improvement of visitor facilities. As for the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), he has yet to visit the island. He has visited everywhere else at massive expense to the taxpayers, but he has not bothered to worry about one of the major international tourist attractions in his own back yard. I say to the Minister, given his flair for the fleas and ticks of Australia's wildlife, that the penguin parade has much to offer and to commend itself to him. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to Australia's participation in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. Recently the Australian National Commission for UNESCO, on which I am the Government's representative, sent to members of both Houses its report for the three-year period 1981 to 1983. That report illustrates the benefit Australia receives from active membership. Its appearance is timely as UNESCO is very much in the public eye. Australia profits nationally by contributing to the development of solutions to problems in education, science, culture and communication around the globe through UNESCO. Participation in UNESCO's international and regional activities helps build bridges that overcome Australia's geographical isolation. Australians are able to attend conferences and workshops and share in ongoing information exchange networks, and thereby gain scientific and technical knowledge useful to the Australian community. For example, Australia takes part in a UNESCO program which examines how the spread of deserts through pastoral and agricultural misuse of land can be prevented, a subject particularly relevant to Australia's needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia also shares in the benefits of UNESCO's work in setting international standards in a host of areas. Member states agree to adhere to the standards through the signing of conventions. As a result of one set of UNESCO conventions, for example, Australian writers get copyright for what they have published overseas. Australia's foreign policy is served through UNESCO as links with other countries, particularly in Asia and the Pacific, are strengthened. In March the Federal Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) was able to meet Asian and Pacific Ministers of Education in Bangkok as a result of a regional UNESCO conference. Further, by making Australian expertise available through consultancies and by staging conferences and workshops in Australia, Australia gains a great deal of goodwill. In February the Australian National Commission for UNESCO, in conjunction with UNESCO in Paris, held a workshop in Melbourne for science journalists from Asian and Pacific countries. One product of this was the spread of information about science in Australia through the media in Asia and the Pacific. During the 1981-83 period nine regional seminars were staged in Australia on subjects ranging from protection of historic places to the marketing of information services. Meanwhile, more than 200 Australians contributed to UNESCO programs overseas as consultants or through attendance at seminars. They were concerned with subjects from education of the handicapped and book publishing to solar energy and South East Asian migration.

All these benefits are gained at relatively little cost to the Australian Government. Australia contributes 1.5 per cent of UNESCO's budget, a figure based on the country's gross national product. In 1985 Australia's contribution was assessed at $US1,335,712. This figure was reduced substantially because of unexpected international currency fluctuations in UNESCO's previous budget period. This led to savings for the Organisation and member states, including Australia, and they will have their 1985 contributions reduced. This year Australia will pay only $US86,368.

Membership of UNESCO entails also the funding of the Australian National Commission for UNESCO. This is a 41-member body made up of academics, community leaders, political representatives and departmental representatives. It advises the Government on policy towards UNESCO, links Australians interested in UNESCO's fields of endeavour with the Organisation, and mounts activities in Australia. Its budget for activities in 1984-85 is $139,000. All members serve without honorarium. In addition, there are costs to the Government in the form of a small secretariat for the National Commission and a full time Ambassador to UNESCO in Paris. This is balanced, however, by the Australians employed in UNESCO's Paris-based secretariat in professional posts. Australia's quota is eight.

Clearly, the cost of belonging to UNESCO is not great, especially considering the benefits that come to Australia in a narrow national sense, not to mention the obligation Australians have to contribute to the solution of world problems as part of humanity. This should not be obscured by the current political criticism of UNESCO, which may mount as the Organisation approaches its general conference in Sofia, Bulgaria, in October. While the Australian Government recognises that reforms are necessary to make UNESCO a more efficient and effective organisation, it has stated that the best way to achieve these reforms is to work from within the Organisation as a positive participant. I support this statement and urge members to take the time to become familiar with the work of UNESCO.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish today to express the anxieties of many Turkish settlers in this country provoked by the visit of the Turkish Foreign Minister. A great number of Turkish families settled in my electorate. They are hard working, good citizens of Australia. A number of them contacted me to express their anxieties about the Turkish Foreign Minister's visit. They fear an intensification of pressures on them by the Turkish Consulate and the intensification of the fear campaign conducted against them and their families by the diplomatic representatives of their former country in Australia. This campaign started after the military coup d'etat. On 12 December 1980 the military seized power in Turkey. The putsch coincided with North Atlantic Treaty Organisation military manoeuvres, for which thousands of United States soldiers arrived in Turkey from West Germany. The seizure of power was announced by the State Department in Washington before the Turkish generals went on the Istanbul radio.

SPEECH.PARA: The first act of the generals after the putsch was to disband the Confederation of Progressive Unions-DISK-arresting 63 of its leaders who now face the death penalty. It also arrested 2,000 of its members. On the day of the military coup the offices of the Turkish Peace Association were ransacked, documents seized and its possessions confiscated. The President, Mohmud Dikerdem, who is aged 68 and is a respected former Ambassador, lecturer on international relations and author, was arrested, together with the executive of the TPA. After a lengthy military show-trial they were sentenced to eight years hard labour, plus two years and eight months internal exile. Amongst the members of the goaled executive are: Dr Erdal Atabek, President of the Turkish Medical Association; Dr Mertin Ozek, Professor of Psychiatry at the Istanbul University; Nedim Tarhan, member of parliament; Nuretin Yilmaz, member of parliament and a former presidential candidate; Ali Taygun, director of the Istanbul State Theatre Co. and many other well-known personalities in the academic, political and artistic elite of Turkey.

Altogether 110,000 people have been goaled and 200,000 people are under surveillance by the authorities. Prisoners are held at least 45 days without trial and are subjected to the most inhuman forms of torture. To subdue the country, the Government is using draconian legislation borrowed from Mussolini's penal code. The violation of human rights is widespread. The junta, to disguise its fascist nature, stage-managed an election in November 1982, when General Kenon Evren was elected as President for seven years, with wide powers based on a new authoritarian constitution. Such are the regime ruling in Turkey today and the Government that the visiting Turkish Foreign Minister represents.

The Turkish Government is not only mistreating its own citizens but is also intimidating Australian citizens of Turkish origin. In 1982, 13 Australian citizens were summoned to return to Turkey and another two have since been summoned. Turkish migrants, who for some years have been settled in Australia, are threatened with confiscation of their properties and they fear for the safety of their families in Turkey. None of those summoned back from Australia has returned, but one person who returned from West Germany after being summoned was arrested and beaten on his arrival and, according to his attorneys, is now in a critical condition.

While we have to extend diplomatic courtesies to the Turkish Foreign Minister, I want Mr Vahit Halefoglo to know that we will not tolerate the use of intimidating fascist tactics against Australian citizens of Turkish origin by diplomats serving under him.
